questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence in which they occur, after the 'p wave' in ECG:

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C- Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) ABDC

Explanation:

The correct sequence after the P wave is as follows:

  • A. 'a' wave: The 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. It occurs during atrial systole when the atria contract to push blood into the ventricles.
  • B. 1st heart sound: The 1st heart sound, also known as S1, is the closure of the atrioventricular (AV) valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) at the beginning of ventricular systole. It marks the onset of ventricular contraction.
  • D. 't' wave: The 't' wave is a repolarization phase of the ventricles. It represents the relaxation and resetting of the ventricles after contraction.
  • C. Rapid filling of ventricles: After the 't' wave, the ventricles enter the diastole phase, during which they passively fill with blood from the atria. This is known as rapid ventricular filling.

Therefore, the correct sequence is ABDC: 'a' wave, 1st heart sound, rapid filling of ventricles, and 't' wave.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not necessary for determining creatinine clearance?

choices.text: The volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) The volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hours

Explanation:

  • Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Plugging in the values:

Cs = (10 ×2)/5  = 4 ml /min

So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min.

 

Types of Clearance Measurements:

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: Determine the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume in a participant who received an injection of 10 grams of mannitol into their venous blood. After reaching equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was observed to be 10%, while the plasma concentration of mannitol measured 65 mg per 100 ml.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) 14L

Explanation:

  • Mannitol is used to measure the extracellular fluid volume compartment because it is freely permeable to the capillary membrane and impermeable to cell membrane.
  • Given in the question:
    • Amount of mannitol injected = 10 g
    • Fraction excreted in urine = 10% = 1gm
    • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100 ml
  • Using the formula of volume distribution (V)
    • V= (Amount injected - Amount excreted) / Concentration
  • Substituting the values into the formula:
    • V = (10g - 1 g) / (65mg / 100 ml)
  • Let's convert the units to be consistent:
    • V = (10,000 mg-1,000 mg)/(65 mg/100 ml)
    • V = 9000mg / (65mg / 100 ml)
    • V = (9000mg x 100ml) / 65 mg
    • V = 900000ml / 65
    • V = 13,846 ml •
    • Finally, converting milliliters to liters V = 13.846 L.
    • Therefore, the correct ECF volume is approximately 13.846 L, which is closest to option 14L.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine, and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Mechanically

Explanation:

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically. This coupling mechanism allows the voltage change across the muscle cell membrane to trigger the opening of the ryanodine receptor, releasing calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm, which is essential for muscle contraction.

Sarcotubular System:

  • The Sarcotubular system is composed of the L tubule T tubule .
  • The T-tubule contains a L-type voltage gated Calcium channel, known as the DHPR (dihydropyridine receptor channel).
  • The L-tubule contains a calcium channel known as RyR ryanodine receptor channel).

  • After the membrane depolarization, the DHPR channel will undergo conformation changes to extend one arm towards the RyR channel, which will lead to a mechanical interaction between the two channels.

questions.text: Which part of the nephron forms the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) DCT

Explanation:

Macula densa:

  • A specialised group of epithelial cells located in the distal convoluted tubule adjacent to the glomerulus.
  • They detect sodium concentration in the filtrate and help regulate blood pressure and filtration rate.

JuxtaGlomerular Apparatus(JG): Crucial for regulating kidney function and blood pressure

Consists of 3 components:

  • Macula densa
  • Juxtaglomerular cells/Granular cells
  • Extraglomerular mesangial cells/Lacis cells

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Hydrophobic

Explanation:

  • The transmembranous part of a membrane receptor spans the lipid bilayer, which consists of hydrophobic fatty acid tails in its core.
  • To integrate into this hydrophobic environment, the transmembrane regions of the receptor must predominantly consist of hydrophobic amino acids. (Option B)
  • These amino acids interact favorably with the hydrophobic lipid tails, ensuring the receptor's stability within the membrane.
  • The charged hydrophilic aminoacids are located on the surfaces (Option C ruled out)

Amphipathic (Option A): While the overall receptor may exhibit amphipathic properties, the transmembrane part specifically requires hydrophobic amino acids. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

Explanation:

Baroreceptor Reflex

Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center (Option B ruled out)
  • It is a rapid negative feedback loop in which an elevated blood pressure causes the heart rate to decrease. Decreased blood pressure decreases baroreflex activation and causes heart rate to increase and to restore blood pressure levels. (Option A)

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength (Option D ruled out)
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

Reflex - Supine to standing" data-author="" data-hash="12135" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="320" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/QLAOdtkOSmvd2OpYr7xO1746516919.png" width="521" />

questions.text: Identify the hormones marked in the image given.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-GHRH B-Somatostatin C-GH D-IGF-1

Explanation:

  1. A (GHRH): Growth hormone-releasing hormone is released by the hypothalamus to stimulate the somatotrophs in the anterior pituitary.
  2. B (Somatostatin): Somatostatin, also released by the hypothalamus, inhibits the release of GH from the anterior pituitary.
  3. C (GH): Growth hormone is released by the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary and acts on the liver.
  4. D (IGF-1): Insulin-like growth factor 1 is produced by the liver in response to GH stimulation.

questions.text: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Explanation:

  • Hashimoto's Thyroiditis is an autoimmune hypothyroid condition presenting with high TSH and low T3/T4.

  • In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly targets the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and damage.

  • Antibodies play a crucial role in this process,

    • Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase (TPO) Antibodies: Target an enzyme called thyroid peroxidase, which helps synthesise thyroid hormones. They are a hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and are frequently elevated in affected individuals.

    • Anti-Thyroglobulin(Tg) Antibodies: Thyroglobulin is a protein involved in thyroid hormone production. Antibodies against thyroglobulin can disrupt hormone synthesis and contribute to thyroid gland damage.

  • These antibodies and other immune cells contribute to the characteristic features of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, including thyroid gland enlargement, decreased thyroid hormone production, and symptoms of hypothyroidism.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option A) is a condition where there is an underproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to low blood calcium levels. It involves low PTH levels and affects calcium balance, but it is not related to thyroid hormone levels.

Pituitary Adenoma (Option B) is a benign tumour of the pituitary gland that can affect its ability to produce hormones, including TSH. It can cause secondary hypothyroidism by not secreting enough TSH, but the given scenario is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism, not secondary (also called central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels).

Grave's disease (Option C) is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, which leads to elevated T4 and suppressed TSH, not low T4 and high TSH. Therefore, this is the opposite of what is presented in the question.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a girl who has experienced continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ectopic ureter

Explanation:

Continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth are classic symptoms of an ectopic ureter.

Ectopic ureter

Etiology
  • It results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication.

Pathology
  • Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, which is commonly associated with duplication of the ureter.

Pathophysiology

  • In females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence.

  • In males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence.

Types

  • Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases).

  • Unilateral ectopic ureters.

Clinical Features

 

  • Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding.

  • Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter.

Diagnosis

  • Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU).

  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU).

Lab Investigations
  • Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU).

Complications

  • Persistent incontinence in females.

  • Potential recurrent urinary tract infections.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux

  • Urethral Stricture: Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence.

  • Neurogenic Bladder

Treatment
  • Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence.

Stress incontinence (Option A) is the involuntary leakage of urine that occurs when there is increased pressure on the bladder, such as during coughing, sneezing, or exercise. It is more common in adults, especially in women, after childbirth or menopause.

Ureterocele (Option B) is the congenital dilation of the distal ureter, which forms a cyst-like structure in the bladder wall. This can obstruct urine flow, potentially causing hydronephrosis or recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

Vesicovaginal fistula (Option D) is an abnormal communication between the bladder and vagina, typically caused by prolonged obstructed labour. This leads to tissue breakdown and formation of a fistula, resulting in continuous leakage of urine through the vagina.

  • Cytokeratin 20 (CK 20) is a marker of epithelial origin expressed in colon cancer.
  • CDX-1 is a transcription factor that is typically expressed in the nuclei of normal intestinal epithelium and is highly specific for colorectal carcinomas.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak is suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ERCP

Explanation:

  • In the context of a suspected bile leak after cholecystectomy, the best investigation is typically ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
  • It can help confirm the presence of a bile leak, localise the site, and allow for therapeutic intervention, such as stenting, which may resolve the leak.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Definition

It is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts, pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder.

Indications
  • It allows for visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater.
  • Allows biopsies, stone extraction, and other Interventional procedures like sphincterotomy, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilation.

In Jaundice

Less suitable for jaundiced patients as it is invasive

Imaging Type

Provides dynamic information during contrast introduction

Image

MRCP (Option A) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help visualise bile ducts, but it doesn't provide the same ability for therapeutic intervention as ERCP.

HIDA (Option C) (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) is useful for evaluating biliary patency and assessing bile flow. Though it can be used for detecting bile flow abnormalities, it cannot be used for therapeutic management, hence ERCP is generally considered the best for diagnosing and managing bile leaks.

CECT (Option D) can be used to detect collections or fluid accumulation and its evaluation but it lacks the therapeutic intervention that ERCP can offer. Additionally, CECT involves radiation exposure and may not be the optimal choice when a more specific investigation like ERCP is available.

questions.text: Which of the following curves represents gamma-globin chain production?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Orange curve

Explanation:

  • α₂γ₂ is the correct composition for fetal hemoglobin (HbF). It consists of two alpha (α) chains and two gamma (γ) chains.
  • By 6-8 weeks gestation, HbF (α2γ2) is the predominant hemoglobin; at 24 weeks gestation, it constitutes 90% of the total hemoglobin.
  • HbF declines modestly in the third trimester, such that the HbF comprises 70–80% of the total hemoglobin.
  • HbF production decreases rapidly postnatally and by 6-12 mo of age reaches adult levels of <2%.

questions.text: Which of the following are used to stop oesophagal variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A, B & C

Explanation:

A) Sengstaken Blakemore Tube: (Option A)

  • Its primary use is Balloon tamponade for controlling variceal bleeding in the oesophagus and stomach.
  • It is also called a four-lumen Minnesota tube or Linton's tube or Modified 4 lumen Pitcher tube.
  • It contains a gastric balloon, esophageal balloon, gastric aspiration port and esophageal aspiration port.

 

B) Minnesota tube: (Option A) It is similar to the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube and is used to control upper GI bleeding, including oesophagal varices, by balloon tamponade.

 

 

C) Upper GI endoscopy: (Option A) It is a crucial tool in managing oesophagal variceal bleeding. While it doesn't directly stop the bleeding, it allows for visualisation of the varices and enables interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to control the bleeding.

 

 

D) Monopolar cautery: It involves the use of electric current to coagulate and stop bleeding from varices. It can be used during endoscopic procedures to target specific bleeding points.

questions.text: In response to increased blood pressure, which of the following is released at the level SA node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ACh

Explanation:

  • In response to increased blood pressure, acetylcholine (ACh) is released at the level of the SA node.
  • Increased blood pressure activates baroreceptors, which stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system to release acetylcholine.
  • This action decreases the heart rate by inhibiting the SA node, helping to lower the blood pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inflammatory carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The presentation of the patient, along with redness and swelling of the right breast with a mobile lump, is suggestive of Inflammatory breast carcinoma.
  • It is a rare but aggressive form of breast cancer characterised by pain, redness, swelling, and warmth of the breast.
  • In Inflammatory breast carcinoma, edematous skin is tethered to the breast by Cooper ligaments and mimics orange peel or peau d’orange.
  • Microscopy shows:
    • No inflammation is present.
    • Diffuse lymphovascular space plugging with carcinoma cells in dermal lymphatics.
  • The presentation can be confused with a breast infection, leading to delayed diagnosis.
  • The stage of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) is always T4d, which corresponds to at least stage III breast cancer. This indicates locally advanced disease with a poor prognosis, though it may be stage IV if distant metastases are present.

Giant fibroadenoma (Option B) is a benign breast tumour that can grow large but is usually firm and mobile. It is not associated with warmth in the breast and is unlikely to cause signs of inflammation, as seen in inflammatory carcinoma.

Phyllodes tumours (Option C), also called cystosarcoma phyllodes are stromal tumours developing from the connective tissue of the breast. Most of them are benign, but a small number can be borderline or malignant. They do not generally cause the redness and skin changes seen in inflammatory breast cancer.

Galactocele (Option D) is a benign lump, which is a milk retention cyst, and it usually occurs in lactating women. It presents as a moderately firm, painless mass that may gradually or rapidly enlarge, with size fluctuations throughout the day. While they are generally painless and non-inflammatory, complications can occasionally lead to infection.

questions.text: Which of the following gene mutations are involved in carcinoma of the colon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) APC, k-ras, p53

Explanation:

  • The genes associated with the development of colorectal carcinoma are APC, k-ras, p53 & SMAD4.
  • Adenoma-Carcinoma Sequence: Accounts for up to 80% of sporadic cancers.
  • APC Gene Mutations:
    • Leads to β-catenin accumulation and Wnt pathway activation.
    • "First hit": Sporadic inactivation of APC.
    • "Second hit": Loss of second APC copy
  • K-ras Mutations:
    • Promote growth and prevent apoptosis.
  • SMAD2 and SMAD4 Mutations:
    • Disrupt TGF-β pathway, causing uncontrolled proliferation.
  • p53 Mutations:
    • Occur in later stages of tumour progression.

 

colorectal cancer" data-author="" data-hash="12179" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="210" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/0wEnjsz1KsbQFf4gR7Mn1746521428.png" width="500" />

Fearon and Vogelstein's model for the development of colorectal cancer

APC, BRCA, k-ras (Option A): BRCA mutations are more commonly associated with breast and ovarian cancers, not colon cancer.

MYh, K-RAS, APC (Option C): MYH-associated polyposis (MAP) is a rare autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the MUTYH gene. It can increase the risk of colorectal cancer, but MUTYH gene mutations are not directly associated with colon cancer.

MYH, p53, DCC (Option D): MYH-associated polyposis (MAP) is a rare autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the MUTYH gene. It can increase the risk of colorectal cancer, but MUTYH gene mutations are not directly associated with colon cancer.

questions.text: According to Strasberg's classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type C

 

Explanation:

  • Right aberrant posterior sectoral duct = accessory duct not part of the main biliary confluence

  • Transected with bile leak = consistent with Type C injury

This is often missed intraoperatively and presents with bilious drainage postoperatively.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injuries

Type A (M/C)

(Option A ruled out)

Cystic duct stump leak or leak from sub-vesical duct of Luschka

Type B

(Option Bruled out)

Ligation or occlusion of aberrant right sectoral duct

Type C

(Option C)

Transection without occlusion of the aberrant right sectoral duct

Type D

(Option D ruled out)

Injury to the lateral wall of the Common hepatic duct

Type E

E1 to E5 Bismuth classification

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

Explanation:

  • The mesh that is most appropriate for use during hernioplasty is Lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • The choice of mesh is important as it affects the outcome of the procedure and the long-term success of the hernia repair.
  • Lightweight:
    • It provides sufficient strength and support while minimising the risk of complications like mesh-related pain and discomfort. The reduced material leads to less inflammation and tissue reaction, which improves patient comfort and recovery. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Large pores:
    • Large-pore meshes allow better tissue integration, enabling the mesh to become well-incorporated into the patient’s tissue. This improves healing and reduces complications like infection or seroma formation. The flexibility of large-pore meshes also helps with the natural movement of the abdominal wall, which is essential for long-term functionality. (Options A & C ruled out)

questions.text: FAST stands for

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

Explanation:

  • Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma is the correct full form of FAST.
  • It is a rapid, non-invasive ultrasound examination used primarily in trauma settings to detect free fluid (such as blood) in the abdomen or Thorax.
  • It can be used to assess the hepatorenal, splenorenal, and pelvis spaces for fluid that is considered to be blood in a trauma case.
  • It is a valuable tool in the early management of trauma patients as it helps identify life-threatening conditions, such as internal bleeding, which may require immediate surgical intervention.

Other options A, C & D are not correct.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with a burn injury. He is covered with burns on his head & neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 45%

Explanation:

  • The correct answer in the given condition is 45% based on the rule of 9.
  • To calculate the percentage of burns, we can use the Rule of Nines, a system commonly used to estimate the body surface area (BSA) affected by burns.
  • Since the patient in the scenario is an adult,
    • Burned area% = Head & neck (9%) + Both upper limbs (18%) + Front & back of the chest (18%) = 45%

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with multiple oral and genital ulcers. The patient claims these ulcers resolve spontaneously and that she experiences such episodes at least four times a year. Ocular examination reveals features of anterior uveitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Behcet’s disease

Explanation:
This patient presents with classic features of Behcet's Disease:

  • Young adult male
  • Mucocutaneous manifestations (oral/genital ulcers)
  • Ocular involvement (uveitis)

Behcet's disease is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers. It is a multi-systemic vasculitis that can affect blood vessels of all sizes. One of the common manifestations of Behcet's disease is uveitis

Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • Uveitis (>50%)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who visits the clinic with complaints of frequent falls and walking difficulties. She also has a history of smoking and type-1 diabetes but no history of hypertension or coronary artery disease. During examination, the patient exhibits weakness in both lower limbs, absent DTR, as well as an unsteady gait. But, there is a decrease in proprioception and vibration sense in both lower limbs. Which of the following statements is correct about the above condition?

choices.text: Only the dorsal column is involved
All these patients with a neurological impairment will show macrocytosis
Vitamin B12 supplements do not improve this condition
Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord, which is commonly caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. SCD primarily affects the posterior (dorsal) and lateral columns (Option A) of the spinal cord. Vitamin B12 supplements (Option C) are the mainstay of treatment for vitamin B12 deficiency, and they can improve the patient's condition. And Copper deficiency may also produce similar symptoms. SACD however, occurs secondary to Vitamin B12 deficiency, can present without macrocytosis (Option B).

Subacute combined degeneration

Description
  • Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts

Etiology
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians) Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection

Clinical features
  • Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement
  • Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement
  • Ataxia: Romberg sign positive
  • DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement)
  • Dementia: reversible with therapy
  • Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints

Investigations
  • Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation
  • Peripheral blood smear: may reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils

 

  • NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well

Management
  • Vitamin B12 supplements

Differential diagnosis
  • Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked

questions.text: For hairy cell leukemia, which drug is considered the preferred choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cladribine

Explanation:

  • Cladribine (also known as 2-chlorodeoxyadenosine or 2-CdA) is a purine analog chemotherapy drug that has shown high efficacy in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia. It is considered the drug of choice because it achieves high response rates and durable remissions in most patients. Deoxycoformycin is also shown to have a good remission rate.

Hairy cell leukemia

Mutations

BRAF V600E

Pathogenesis

Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells).

Clinical Presentation

Presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, and symptoms related to splenomegaly (e.g., early satiety, abdominal discomfort), pancytopenia

Peripheral Blood Findings
  • Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings
  • Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells".
  • Fried egg appearance.

Diagnosis
  • Flow cytometry
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation

Treatment
  • Splenectomy: Often leads to prolonged remission.
  • Nucleosides (Cladribine, Deoxycoformycin): Highly effective but cause immunosuppression;
  • Interferon-α (Option D): Effective but less so than nucleosides.
  • Vemurafenib (Option B) (BRAF inhibitor): Used in chemotherapy-refractory cases; not curative but maintains response with chronic use.
  • Vemurafenib + Rituximab (Option A): Leads to more durable remissions.

Prognosis

Excellent

 

While rituximab has shown efficacy in the treatment of various B-cell lymphomas, it is not the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is the preferred treatment for HCL.

Vemurafenib is a targeted therapy drug primarily used for the treatment of certain forms of metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

Interferon-alpha is a type of immunotherapy that has been used in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia in the past. It is now less commonly used.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is experiencing pain in the area surrounding his knee joint. The following lesion visible on the X-ray is seen extending from the distal femur to the terminal end. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Based on the demographics of the patient, clinical manifestation, and X-ray showing sunburst appearance, the most probable diagnosis is osteosarcoma. It most commonly originates in the metaphysis of long bones.

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

Pathology:

  • Origin: It arises from mesenchymal cells.
  • Common site: From the metaphysis or meta-diaphysis
  • Order of frequency: Lower-end of the femur > upper-end of the tibia > upper-end of the humerus.
Types base on Clinical Setting 

Primary osteosarcoma 

  • No known pre-malignant conditions related to it. 
  • Age group: 15-25 years

Secondary osteosarcoma 

  • Pre-malignant conditions are often associated with it. 
  • Paget's disease, multiple enchondromatosis, fibrous dysplasia, irradiation to bones, multiple osteochondroma. 
  • Older age group

 

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate.

Histopathology: Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:

  • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
  • Sun-ray appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

 

 

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle.

CT scan is primarily used to assist with biopsy and disease staging.

Incorrect Options:

Giant Cell Tumor (Option A):

  • Benign but aggressive tumor, typically affecting older adolescents/adults.
  • Seen in the epiphysis, not typically with the "sunburst" appearance.
  • Usually localized, not extending aggressively like osteosarcoma.

Chondroblastoma (Option B):

  • Benign tumor, usually in the epiphysis of long bones.
  • Common in adolescents but lacks aggressive features like periosteal reactions seen in osteosarcoma.

Osteoid Osteoma (Option C):

  • Benign tumor causing localized pain, often relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Small lesion with central nidus and sclerosis, no aggressive periosteal reaction.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 22-year-old male patient presenting with a history of accident, exhibiting leg abduction and external rotation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anterior dislocation of the hip

Explanation:

Anterior hip dislocation

Classification
  • Type I: Pubic (superior) injuries
  • Type II: Obturator (inferior) injuries

Management
  • Reduction should be performed as soon as possible under sedation or general anesthesia.
  • Closed reduction technique:
    • Hold the affected leg in external rotation, abduction, and flexion.
    • Apply longitudinal traction.
    • Internally and externally rotate the leg until reduction is achieved, and apply anterior pressure on the femoral head if necessary.
    • If repeated attempts fail, consider an open reduction.

Complications
  • Injury to the sciatic nerve.
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head: may require hip replacement if osteoarthritis develops.

 

 

  •   Osteoarthritis: develops years later. Treatment varies from conservative to total hip replacement.

 

  • Myositis Ossificans: Develops weeks to months post-injury and is characterized by pain and stiffness. Ill-advised vigorous and improper massage following trauma is the most common cause.Treatment includes rest and analgesics.

 

  • Potential for associated femoral head fractures.

 

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B ruled out)

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

 

 

 

 

An Intertrochanteric fracture (Option C) is a fracture of the femur that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanter. It typically presents with pain and inability to bear weight, but not necessarily with leg abduction and external rotation. This injury is usually associated with falls or trauma but doesn't typically cause the specific positioning of the leg seen in dislocations.

A fracture of the femoral neck (Option D) typically presents with shortening, external rotation, and abduction of the leg, but this injury is more commonly seen in elderly patients with osteoporosis, particularly following falls. While there can be external rotation, abduction is more characteristic of a posterior dislocation or intertrochanteric fracture rather than a femoral neck fracture.

questions.text: What is the most specific test used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Durkan's test

Explanation:

  • Carpal Compression Test or Median Compression Test or Durkan’s test is a diagnostic test of carpal tunnel syndrome. It involves applying direct pressure over the carpal tunnel for 30 seconds. If the patient experiences numbness, pain, or paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve, the test is considered positive.

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Definition

Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist
  • Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to constant symptoms, hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Carpal Compression Test/ Durkan test: Diagnostic test. Positive if pain/paresthesias occur during pressure application over the carpal tunnel.
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms. (Option C ruled out)

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

Two-point discrimination (Option D): This test assesses sensory function, specifically the ability to distinguish between two separate points of stimulation. While a loss of two-point discrimination can be a sign of carpal tunnel syndrome, this test is more general for sensory assessment and not as specific for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome as Durkan's test.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in the medicine ward with a fever. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Leptospirosis

Explanation:

  • Graphical representation shows that over time, the disease leads to complications such as uveitis and interstitial nephritis. And CSF is a reservoir for the causative organism and it is shedding through urine. These findings point towards a diagnosis of leptospirosis.
  • Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection caused by the bacteria of the genus Leptospira. It is commonly transmitted to humans through contact with water, soil, or food contaminated with the urine of infected animals. Leptospirosis can present with symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle aches, and can progress to more severe manifestations, including liver and kidney involvement.

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.
  • Exposure to flooded rice paddies.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features: High fever, severe headache, muscle pain, conjunctival suffusion, and jaundice
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Treatment
  • DOC: Penicillin 6 million units daily.
  • Alternate drugs:
    • Doxycycline
    • Amoxicillin
    • Ampicillin
    • Ceftriaxone

Prevention
  • Avoid contaminated water and use protective clothing
  • Livestock vaccination, proper waste disposal
  • Rodent control measures: Zinc phosphide

 

Life cycle of Leptospirosis:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumour in the retroperitoneal space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Liposarcoma

Explanation:

  • Liposarcoma is the most commonly seen malignant tumour of the retroperitoneum, accounting for a significant portion of retroperitoneal tumours.
  • They are the most common adult sarcoma and commonly occur in the sixth and seventh decades.
  • Three subtypes are:
    • Well-differentiated: chromosome 12 amplification, including p53 inhibitor MDM2.
    • Myxoid: t(12;16) translocation.
    • Pleomorphic

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option B) is a malignant tumour arising from skeletal muscle progenitors. It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents, and it commonly presents in the extremities, not the retroperitoneum.

Synovial sarcoma (Option C) is a rare, slow-growing cancer that affects the soft tissues. It is commonly found in the arm, leg, or foot, and joints such as the wrist or ankle but it is not very common in retroperitoneum.

Neurofibroma (Option D) is a benign nerve sheath tumour often associated with neurofibromatosis. While it can occur in the retroperitoneum, it is not as common as liposarcoma in that region.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes an ideal candidate for a renal graft transplant in a patient with diabetic nephropathy?

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

Explanation:

  • Renal transplantation is considered the treatment of choice for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in patients with diabetic nephropathy with eGFR <20 ml/min.

Renal transplant procedure:

  • Preparation of the donor kidney: inspected and examined. The left kidney is preferred as it has a longer left renal vein.

Operative technique:

  • The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the iliac fossae (retroperitoneal location) leaving the native kidney in situ. Hence, a total of 3 kidneys in the recipient.
  • The donor renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac vein.
  • In a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac artery.
  • In live donors, end-to-end anastomosis to the divided internal iliac artery is used more commonly due to the lack of an aortic patch (Carrel’s patch).

Indications for renal transplantation:

  • End-stage renal disease caused by:
    • Glomerulonephritis
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
    • Renal vascular disease
    • Polycystic Kidney disease/Chronic Pyelonephritis
    • Obstructive uropathy
    • SLE
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Metabolic disease (oxalosis, amyloid)
  • Mnemonic: GD for HR POSt at 4 AM

 

"The survival rate of the graft is 95% in the first year," (Option A) is an overgeneralization. While the survival rate of renal grafts in the first year can be relatively high, it is not consistently 95% for all patients.

"The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant," (Option C) is not entirely accurate. While renal transplantation can improve the quality of life and increase life expectancy in patients with ESRD, it does not necessarily double the life expectancy.

"The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years," (Option D) is not directly addressed in the given statement. Chronic rejection remains a challenge in renal transplantation.

questions.text: A diabetic patient walks into your clinic and does “namaste”. The image is given below. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cheiroarthropathy

Explanation:

  • Cheiroarthropathy is related to long-standing poor glycemic control and the accumulation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) in the skin and soft tissues.This can cause difficulty in fully extending the fingers, leading to a characteristic hand posture resembling the "namaste" gesture.

 

While flexor tenosynovitis (Option A) can occur in individuals with diabetes, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture mentioned in the question.

 

Although Dupuytren's contracture (Option C) is associated with certain risk factors, such as family history and alcoholism, it is not directly related to the "namaste" gesture.

 

While ankylosis (Option D) can occur in various conditions, including certain forms of arthritis, trauma, or infection, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture in the context of a diabetic patient.

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pin tract infections

Explanation:

  • Ring sequestrum is a type of sequestrum commonly seen in pin tract infections. These infections occur at the site where pins or wires from an external fixator penetrate the skin and bone. The infection can cause the bone to form a "ring-like" sequestrum around the pin, which is a hallmark of pin tract infections.

Types of Sequestrum

Type

Disease

Tubular

Pyogenic

Ring

External Fixator (Pin tract infections)

Black

Actinomycosis

Coralliform

Perthe’s Disease

Coke

Tuberculosis

Sandy

Tuberculosis

Feathery/ Ivory

Syphilis

 

Coke sequestrum Ring sequestrum

 

 

Tubular sequestrum

Incorrect Options:

Fungal infections (Option A) can cause bone involvement (e.g., osteomyelitis), but they typically do not produce a "ring sequestrum" on X-ray. The sequestrum in fungal infections tends to be more irregular and less characteristic than the ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

Septic arthritis (Option B) is an infection of the joint, not directly involving the bone. While septic arthritis can lead to secondary bone involvement and osteomyelitis (infection of the bone), it is not typically associated with the formation of a "ring sequestrum".

Acute osteomyelitis (Option D) involves a bone infection, usually caused by bacteria, but it typically results in an irregular or amorphous sequestrum. Acute osteomyelitis usually presents with widespread bone destruction, rather than the isolated, ring-shaped sequestrum seen in pin tract infections.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is least injured during thyroid surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Marginal mandibular nerve

Explanation:

The marginal mandibular nerve innervates the muscles of the lower lip and is the least at risk during thyroid surgery. It is not directly involved or at risk during thyroid surgery, as it is not in close proximity to the thyroid gland.

 

Complications of Thyroidectomy

Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding from muscular arteries or slippage of ligature from superior thyroid vessels.
  • Complication: Tension hematoma causing respiratory distress. Management: Immediate re-operation, open sutures, control bleeding, drain hematoma, and close the wound.

Respiratory Obstruction
  • Primary Cause: Laryngeal edema from extubation injury. (Most Common Complication)
  • Other Causes: RLN palsy and tension hematoma.

Nerve Injury
  • Commonly Injured Nerve: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Other Injuries: RLN Injury causing palsy and Cervical sympathetic trunk causing Horner's syndrome. (Options A & B ruled out)

Parathyroid Insufficiency
  • Ligating the inferior thyroid artery away from the thyroid leads to parathyroid vascular infarction.
  • Causes hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) presenting 2–5 days post-surgery.

Thyroid Insufficiency

Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism and requires lifelong levothyroxine replacement.

Thyrotoxic Crisis

Inadequate preoperative preparation in hyperthyroid patients leads to the release of thyroid hormones during surgery.

The external laryngeal nerve (Option C) is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve that innervates the cricothyroid muscle, and it can be injured during thyroidectomy.

questions.text: In hemiplegia caused by an ischemic stroke, which region of the internal capsule is impacted?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Posterior limb

Explanation:

  • When an ischemic stroke occurs in the area supplied by the blood vessels surrounding the posterior limb of the internal capsule, the motor fibers within this region can be damaged. This results in hemiplegia on the opposite side of the body from the affected internal capsule.

Small vessel stroke:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis

Risk factors
  • Hypertension: Most common
  • Diabetes
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Smoking
  • Hyperlipidemia

Sites & manifestations

Posterior limb of internal capsule

Pure motor hemiparesis

Genu of internal capsule

Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness)

Cortical pontocerebellar tract

I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis

Ventroposterolateral thalamus

Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

 

Tracts Passing Through Internal Capsule:

  • Genu:
    • Corticonuclear tract (motor fibres to cranial nerve motor nuclei)
  • Posterior Limb:
    • Corticospinal tract (motor fibres to the contralateral spinal cord)
    • Corticopontine fibres from the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes
    • Fibres for the upper limb (anteriorly) and trunk/lower limbs (posteriorly)
    • Superior Thalamic Peduncle (through anterior and posterior limbs): From ventral posterior and lateral posterior thalamic nuclei to parietal cortex (sensory areas).

Other Tracts Passing Through the Internal Capsule:

Anterior limb

Retrolentiform part

Sublentiform part
  • Frontopontine fibres (Arnold's bundle)
  • Corticorubral fibres
  • Parietopontine,occipitopontine, and occipitotectal fibres
  • Optic radiation
  • Temporopontine fibres
  • Auditory radiation (fibres from the medial geniculate body to the auditory cortex)
  • Thalamic fibres to the temporal cortex and amygdala.

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 20 G

Explanation:

  • The pink-coloured cannula refers to a cannula with a gauge size of 20.
  • The pink cannula is used for rapid fluid replacement & routine blood transfusions.

 

Colour code

Gauge

Flow rate (ml/min)

Indications

Orange

Used in surgical procedures and trauma

Grey

(Option A ruled out)

Used in surgical procedures and trauma

Green

(Option B ruled out)

In Trauma and quick blood transfusions

Pink

Blue

(Option D ruled out)

22

Used in children and older adults

Yellow

Used in neonates and children

Violet

26

13
