questions.text: A counterforce brace is used in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tennis elbow

Explanation:

  • A counterforce brace is primarily used for treating tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis). It helps reduce the strain on the tendons by applying pressure to the forearm, which relieves pain and allows the muscles to rest.

Lateral epicondylitis (Tennis elbow)

Definition

A condition characterized by pain and tenderness at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus due to non-specific inflammation at the origin of the extensor muscles of the forearm

Causes
  • Overuse of extensor muscles
  • Repetitive activities (e.g., tennis, typing, using mouse)
  • Non-specific inflammation at muscle origin

Clinical Features
  • Pain and tenderness precisely localized to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain aggravated by extending the wrist against resistance
  • Normal X-ray findings

Tests
  • Cozen's test: Also known as the resisted wrist extension test or resistive tennis elbow test, this test involves the patient making a fist and resisting wrist extension while the examiner applies pressure. The test is positive if the patient experiences pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley's test: This test involves the patient pronating their forearm and resisting extension of the third digit of their hand while the examiner stabilizes the humerus. The test is positive if the patient experiences sudden pain on the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mills's test: Another common test for tennis elbow.

Treatment
  • Initial: Analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs
  • If no response: Local injection of hydrocortisone at the point of maximum tenderness
  • Physical therapy and activity modification

Incorrect Options:

Ankle Sprain (Option B) typically requires ankle supports, braces, or wraps for immobilization and stabilization, but not specifically a counterforce brace. Treatment usually involves rest, ice, compression, and elevation (R.I.C.E.), along with possible rehabilitation exercises.

Ulnar Claw Hand (Option C), a deformity caused by damage to the ulnar nerve, requires splints or other supportive devices to manage the hand’s positioning and function. A counterforce brace is not used for this condition; a static or dynamic splint is typically used to improve function.

Foot Drop (Option D), a condition characterized by difficulty lifting the foot due to weakness or paralysis of the anterior tibialis muscle, is usually treated with ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) to support the foot and prevent dragging. A counterforce brace is not typically used for foot drop.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been declared brain dead, and her family has chosen to donate her organs. Who would be the most suitable recipient of her organs?

choices.text: 50-year alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 32 year old woman with renal failure

Explanation:

  • A 32-year-old woman with renal failure is the most suitable recipient for the donor's organs as the age match between the donor and the recipient increases the likelihood of a successful transplant.
  • When it comes to organ donation, the primary considerations for choosing the recipient include matching the donor's organ characteristics such as size, blood type, and tissue compatibility, as well as the recipient's health status and likelihood of receiving benefit from the transplant.
  • Optimal transplantation involves choosing donors and recipients of similar age, among other factors, to minimise compatibility challenges

14-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (Option A): A 14-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome is likely to have a more complicated prognosis, and the organs of a 32-year-old woman may not be the best match for a pediatric recipient.

50-year alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1-month abstinence (Option B): Even though he has been abstinent for a month, liver transplant eligibility often requires a longer period of sobriety, as relapse can occur and impact the success of the transplant. Additionally, liver transplants are often prioritized for individuals with urgent needs or a better prognosis.

70-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (Option C): The 70-year-old woman's potential benefit from a kidney transplant needs careful consideration of her age and associated comorbidities.

questions.text: The brace shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Milwaukee brace

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the Milwaukee brace.
  • The Milwaukee brace is used for structural scoliosis and fits snugly over the pelvis. It includes chin and head pads for active postural correction and a thoracic pad that presses on the ribs at the apex of the curve. While it is cumbersome, if well-made, it does not significantly interfere with activity. However, bracing is now used less frequently due to doubts about its effectiveness in altering the progression of scoliosis.

 

 

Boston brace (Option A): The Boston brace is used for low lumbar curves in scoliosis and does not include a head or chin component. It is a more streamlined brace that typically only covers the torso.

Taylor brace (Option C): The Taylor brace is used for spinal fractures or for patients recovering from spinal surgery. It provides support to the lumbar and lower thoracic spine but does not have the design elements (chin or head pads) seen in the Milwaukee brace.

ASHE brace (Option D): The ASHE (Anterior Spinal Hyperextension) brace is used to provide hyperextension support for the lumbar spine but is not used for scoliosis. It has a completely different structure compared to the Milwaukee brace.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalised abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute mesenteric ischemia

Explanation:

  • Acute mesenteric ischemia is the most likely diagnosis due to the patient's risk factors (IHD), sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, hypotension, and absent bowel sounds.
  • This condition is caused by a reduction or cessation of blood flow to the intestines, leading to tissue ischemia.

Acute mesenteric ischemia

Aspects

Description

Definition
  • Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis.
  • Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

Clinical Features
  • Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings.
  • Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock.

Risk Factors
  • Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure.
  • Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis.
  • Others: Hypercoagulable states.

Radiological Features

CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign, bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas.

Management
  • Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control.
  • Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Acute severe pancreatitis (Option A) presents with severe epigastric pain that can radiate to the back, but not generalised abdominal pain. The patient also often has elevated pancreatic enzymes (amylase/lipase), and abdominal tenderness would usually be present. The absence of bowel sounds and the patient's cardiac symptoms are suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia.

Ruptured aortic aneurysm (Option B) is a life-threatening condition that causes severe, tearing abdominal pain and sudden, severe hypotension. This patient lacks key signs like a pulsatile mass, significant tenderness, or acute collapse, making it less likely.

Peptic ulcer perforation (Option D) presents with acute abdominal pain, tachycardia, guarding and rigidity of the anterior abdominal wall, it can lead to peritonitis and sepsis. The soft, non-distended abdomen in this case and the absence of these physical findings suggest this is less likely.

questions.text: To which part of the vertebra are the screws fixed in spine fusion surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pedicle

Explanation:

  • In spine fusion surgery, screws are typically inserted into the pedicle of the vertebra. The pedicle is a bony structure that connects the vertebral body to the posterior elements (lamina and spinous processes), making it an ideal anchor point for screws. Pedicle screws provide strong fixation and allow for effective stabilization of the spine during fusion.

Incorrect Options:

Spinous process (Option A): The spinous process is the bony protrusion at the back of the vertebra, and it is not used for screw fixation in spine fusion surgery, as it does not provide enough stability.

Lamina (Option B): The lamina is part of the vertebra's posterior structure, but it is not the primary anchor point for screws in fusion surgery.

Facet joint (Option D): Facet joints are involved in the movement between vertebrae, but screws are not typically fixed into the facet joints for spine fusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Mycoplasma pneumoniae?

choices.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Responds well to Amoxiclav

Explanation:

  • Amoxiclav, which is a combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid, is not considered a first-line treatment for Mycoplasma pneumonia. The drug of choice for Mycoplasma pneumoniae is Azithromycin.

Atypical Pneumonia (Walking Pneumonia)

Definition

Atypical pneumonia is a milder form of pneumonia, often caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, certain viruses, or moulds.

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, chest pain, headache, and chills, resembling a bad cold.
  • As it is generally mild, not requiring bed rest or hospitalization, allowing people to continue daily activities called"walking pneumonia."

Etiologic Agents
  • Atypical pneumonia is caused by organisms that don't grow on standard cultures or appear on Gram stain, such as:
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia (associated with closed living conditions like at school and military barracks)
    • Chlamydia pneumoniae
    • Legionella species (from stagnant water sources or from air conditioners)
    • Respiratory viruses: Influenza, adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), human metapneumoviruses, and coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2)

Prevalence
  • Cases of atypical pneumonia are increasing, particularly among young adults.

Diagnosis
  • These pathogens cannot be cultured in the usual ways, making diagnosis more complex.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a unique bacterium that lacks a cell wall and requires a specialized cell-free medium for culture (Option D) as it cannot be grown on conventional culture media.
  • Detection of specific antibodies (Option B) (IgM and IgG) against Mycoplasma pneumoniae, can be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.
  • PCR and other molecular methods are often necessary for confirmation.

Radiology

  • Chest X-ray findings in Mycoplasma pneumonia can vary, but bilateral infiltrates (Option C) are commonly seen. Infiltrates may appear as patchy or diffuse opacities in both lungs. However, chest X-ray findings alone cannot definitively diagnose Mycoplasma pneumonia and should be correlated with clinical symptoms and other diagnostic tests.

Treatment
  • The absence of a cell wall makes these organisms resistant to certain antibiotics that target cell wall synthesis, such as penicillins and cephalosporins and require treatment with macrolides like azithromycin, and fluoroquinolones, or tetracyclines like doxycycline.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, and vomiting is diagnosed with biliary dyskinesia. Which of the following is least useful in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) USG

Explanation:

  • Biliary dyskinesia is a functional disorder of the gallbladder, characterised by abnormal motility and diagnosis is typically made through tests that evaluate gallbladder function rather than its structure.
  • USG is good for detecting structural abnormalities, but it does not assess gallbladder function.
  • It presents with intermittent upper abdominal pain and nausea, particularly after eating, when your gallbladder attempts to contract (biliary colic) and the insufficient bile in the intestine leads to bloating, nausea, vomiting, and poor digestion, especially after consuming fatty foods.
  • HIDA scan is useful in diagnosis, as it evaluates gallbladder function using a radioactive tracer. (Option B ruled out)


ERCP (Option A) is not the first-line test for biliary dyskinesia, but it is used to assess biliary dysmotility by using a manometry. It is also useful for visualizing the biliary ducts and can help rule out anatomical causes of biliary pain; it also provides an opportunity for therapeutic interventions if needed.

Post-surgery follow-up (Option D) is not used to diagnose biliary dyskinesia but is important for monitoring recovery and addressing complications, as well as for managing and assessing the patient's condition after surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the first air cell of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Agger nasi

Explanation:

  • The Agger nasi is the first and most anterior air cell of the anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is located just beneath the frontal sinus and is often visible on CT scans of the paranasal sinuses.
  • It is situated near the middle turbinate and is a key landmark in the anatomy of the anterior ethmoid region.

Agger Nasi:

  • The Agger nasi is the anterior-most ethmoidal air cell and forms part of the anterior ethmoid complex.
  • It is typically seen in sinus imaging, and its location is important in surgical procedures such as functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).
  • The Agger nasi often drains into the middle meatus and may contribute to sinus congestion when obstructed.

Incorrect Options:

Bulla ethmoidalis (Option A): is incorrect because the bulla ethmoidalis is a larger air cell in the middle part of the ethmoid sinus, not the first one.

Onodi cell (Option B): is incorrect because the Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that lies near the sphenoid sinus, not the anterior ethmoidal cells.

Haller cell (Option D): is incorrect because the Haller cell is a variant air cell located in the floor of the orbit and not part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus system.

questions.text:
Match the following

1. Urine Bag

2. Nasogastric Tube

3. Underwater seal bag

4. Suction cannula
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Explanation:

1. Urine Bag

It is a collection bag attached to a catheter inserted into the urinary bladder to collect and measure urine

2. Nasogastric Tube

It is flexible tube inserted through the nose and down into the stomach for various diagnostic or therapeutic

purposes.

3. Underwater seal bag

A device used in chest drainage systems to maintain a seal and prevent air from entering the pleural space

4. Suction cannula

It is a hollow tube used for the removal of fluid or secretions through suction.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a division of external carotid artery within Kiesselback's plexus?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Anterior Ethmoidal Artery

Explanation:

  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, which is derived from the internal carotid artery, not the external carotid artery.
  • Therefore, it is not a division of the external carotid artery and does not contribute to Kiesselbach's plexus.

Kiesselbach’s Plexus:

  • Kiesselbach's plexus is a vascular network located on the anterior part of the nasal septum, composed of arteries from the external carotid artery. The common arteries involved in Kiesselbach's plexus include:
    • Sphenopalatine artery (from the maxillary artery)
    • Greater palatine artery (from the maxillary artery)
    • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (from the facial artery) These vessels contribute to the blood supply to the nasal septum and are involved in conditions such as epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Incorrect Options:

Sphenopalatine artery (Option B): is incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid, and it contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus.

Greater palatine artery (Option C): is incorrect because the greater palatine artery is also a branch of the maxillary artery and contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus.

Septal branch of superior labial (Option D): is incorrect because the septal branch of the superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery, also part of the external carotid, and contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus.

questions.text: In a case of otitis media, which of the following is absent?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Battle sign

Explanation:

  • Battle sign refers to bruising behind the ear, which is often indicative of a basilar skull fracture. This is not typically associated with otitis media.
  • Otitis media itself does not lead to Battle sign but can lead to complications such as Bezold abscess, Griesinger’s sign. 

Otitis Media:

  • Otitis media is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear that can lead to a variety of complications, especially when it becomes chronic or severe.
  • Griesinger's sign (pain when pulling the ear) and Bezold abscess (a deep neck abscess) are known complications.
  • However, Battle sign typically suggests trauma, such as a basilar skull fracture, and is not a direct manifestation of otitis media.

Incorrect Options:

Bezold abscess (Option A): is incorrect because a Bezold abscess is a known complication of otitis media, particularly when the infection spreads into the mastoid.

Griesinger’s sign (Option B): is incorrect because Griesinger’s sign is a clinical finding of pain and tenderness when pulling the ear, often seen in otitis media.

Delta sign (Option D): is incorrect because the Delta sign is unrelated to otitis media and typically refers to a sign seen in epidural hematoma.

questions.text:
The components of qSOFA scoring include:

A. Mental status

B. Blood pressure

C. Respiratory rate

D. Heart rate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A, B & C

Explanation:

  • qSOFA is quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment scoring, and it uses 3 components, i.e.;
    • Respiratory rate (≥ 22 breaths per minute)
    • Altered mental status (GCS ≤ 15)
    • Low systolic blood pressure (≤ 100)
  • qSOFA is a bedside score that helps identify patients at risk of death from a suspected infection.
  • Heart rate is not included in the qSOFA score. (Statement D ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the correct answer related to the nerve injuries in various surgeries:

 


	
		
			
			A. Breast surgery
			
			
			1. External Laryngeal nerve
			
		
		
			
			B. Thyroid surgery
			
			
			2. Hypoglossal nerve
			
		
		
			
			C. Submandibular excision
			
			
			3. Phrenic nerve
			
		
		
			
			D. Thymectomy
			
			
			4. Long Thoracic Nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Explanation:

A. Breast surgery

4. Long Thoracic Nerve

  • This nerve is commonly injured during breast surgery, leading to a "winged scapula”.
  • Breast surgery can also lead to Thoracodorsal nerve injury.

B. Thyroid surgery

1. External Laryngeal nerve

  • It is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and innervates the cricothyroid muscle; it can be injured during thyroidectomy.
  • It leads to hoarseness and difficulty in pitch modulation.

C. Submandibular excision

2. Hypoglossal nerve

  • It supplies motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue.
  • It runs near the submandibular gland and can be injured during its excision, leading to deviation of the tongue towards the affected side.

D. Thymectomy

3. Phrenic nerve

  • The phrenic nerve may be injured during thymectomy, leading to diaphragm paralysis.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests are used to objectively assess hearing ability? 


	BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)
	OAE (Otoacoustic Emission)
	PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry)
	Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry):
    • This is an objective test that measures the electrical activity of the auditory nerve and brainstem in response to sound stimuli.
    • It is typically used to assess the hearing of individuals who cannot perform behavioral hearing tests, such as infants or individuals with disabilities.
  • OAE (Otoacoustic Emission):
    • This is also an objective test used to assess the function of the outer hair cells of the cochlea.
    • It detects sound waves that are generated by the cochlea when it responds to auditory stimuli, helping assess hearing ability, especially in infants and young children.
  • Tympanometry:
    • This test measures the movement of the eardrum in response to changes in air pressure.
    • It helps assess middle ear function but does not directly measure hearing sensitivity.
    • However, it is an important tool in objective hearing assessments as it helps identify issues such as fluid in the ear or eustachian tube dysfunction.

Objective Hearing Tests:

  • Objective hearing tests do not require a response from the patient and are used to assess the integrity and function of different parts of the auditory pathway.
  • These tests include BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry.
  • Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA), however, is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's ability to respond to various tones, and thus, it is not considered an objective test.

Incorrect Options:

1, 2 and 3 (Option B): Incorrect because PTA is subjective and requires the patient's response to tones, unlike the other tests.

2, 3 and 4 (Option C): Incorrect because PTA is a subjective test.

1, 2, 3 and 4 (Option D): Incorrect because PTA is subjective, not objective.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, the ear has swelling, tenderness, and discoloration. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Resolves spontaneously

Explanation:

  • The condition described is likely auricular hematoma, which occurs due to the accumulation of blood between the ear's cartilage and the perichondrium (the tissue covering the cartilage). It is a common result of trauma to the ear and leads to swelling, tenderness, and discoloration.
  • False statement: "Resolves spontaneously" is false. Auricular hematomas typically do not resolve spontaneously and require timely treatment. If left untreated, the blood collection can lead to cartilage necrosis, resulting in deformities like cauliflower ear (pugilistic ear). Treatment usually involves drainage of the accumulated blood and often the use of a pressure dressing to prevent re-accumulation of blood.

Auricular Hematoma:

  • Auricular hematomas require intervention, usually involving drainage and sometimes the use of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.
  • If untreated or improperly managed, the condition can lead to permanent deformities of the ear (like cauliflower ear), commonly seen in boxers or wrestlers (hence the term pugilistic ear).

All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is true as there is a risk of infection, and antibiotics are used to prevent bacterial infections like auricular cellulitis or chondritis.

May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. If auricular hematoma is untreated or inadequately treated, it may lead to cauliflower ear, which is a permanent deformed ear.

Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is true. Auricular hematoma occurs due to blood collecting between the cartilage of the ear and the perichondrium, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.

questions.text: Identify the retractor shown in the below image.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Mollison retractor

Explanation:

  • The Mollison retractor is a surgical instrument used primarily in ear surgery (otology).
  • It is designed to retract soft tissues such as skin or mucosa in the ear during procedures, providing better visibility and access to the surgical site.

Types of Mastoid Retractors

  • Mollison’s Mastoid Retractor:
    • Self-retaining
    • Hemostatic (stops bleeding)

(Mnemonic: Mollison has 8 letters , so it has 4*4 teeth for identification)

  • Jansen’s Mastoid Retractor:
    • Self-retaining
    • Similar to Mollison’s
    • Use: Both retractors are used after incision and flap elevation to retract soft tissues.

(Mnemonic: Jansen has 6 letters, so it has 3*3 teeth for identification)

  • Lempert’s endaural retractor: Endaural approach during ear surgery.

 

  • Lempert’s endaural speculum: Opens the meatus for endaural incision or local injections.

  • Perkin’s mastoid retractor:
    • Self retaining
    • Hemostatic
    • Use: For retraction of soft tissue during mastoidectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Plester's Retractor (Option A): This is a type of retractor used in various surgical fields, particularly in orthopedic procedures, to retract tissues and provide better exposure during surgery.

Wietlaner’s Retractor (Option B): This is a self-retaining retractor used in surgery to retract tissue and maintain an open wound or incision. It is commonly used in ENT and general surgery.

Jansens Retractor (Option D): This is a type of retractor used in ear and nasal surgeries for retracting soft tissues and providing better surgical access.

questions.text:
Match the following weapons with the potential injuries they may cause:


	
		
			
			A. Axe
			
			
			1. Incised wound
			
		
		
			
			B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)
			
			
			2. Train track bruise
			
		
		
			
			C. Blade
			
			
			3. Grazed abrasion
			
		
		
			
			D. Lathi
			
			
			4. Chop wound
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

Explanation:

  • Axe → Chop wound (A-4):
    • An axe is a heavy, sharp weapon that produces deep, clean-cut injuries with underlying bone damage, characteristic of a chop wound.
  • RTA → Grazed abrasion (B-3):
    • In road traffic accidents, grazed abrasions are common due to friction between the skin and rough surfaces like roads.
  • Blade → Incised wound (C-1):
    • A blade produces incised wounds, which are sharp, clean cuts with minimal tissue bridging, often seen in sharp force trauma.
  • Lathi → Train track bruise (D-2):
    • A lathi (baton) produces parallel linear bruises, known as "train track bruises," due to the forceful impact of a cylindrical object.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of snakebite in India?

choices.text: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite

Explanation:

  • Atropine and neostigmine are not routinely used as primary treatment for krait bites.
  • While neostigmine may assist in reversing neurotoxic paralysis caused by snake venom (e.g., postsynaptic blockade in some bites), its role is secondary to antivenom therapy and ventilatory support.
  • Atropine is given to counteract bradycardia caused by neostigmine but is not specific to krait bites.

Treatment of snake bite:

First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’

CARRY
  • Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible.

NO
  • No Suction
  • No Cautery
  • No Ligature
  • No Tourniquet

RIGHT
  • R: Reassure the patient
  • I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps)
  • GH: Get to the Hospital immediately
  • T: Tell history/symptoms

Pressure bandage
  • Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps.
  • Contraindicated in viper bites.
  • Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg.

ASV
  • Mainstay of treatment.
  • Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present
  • Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites.
  • Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age.
  • Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom
  • Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV.
  • Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite.
  • To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites).

Adjuvant treatment
  • Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite).
  • Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach.
  • Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites.


Incorrect Options:

Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV (Option B): Neostigmine may help reverse neurotoxic effects (especially postsynaptic) when combined with ventilatory support. Anti-snake venom (ASV) remains the primary treatment.

ASV is the mainstay of treatment (Option C): Polyvalent ASV is the mainstay for treating bites from the "big four" venomous snakes in India (cobra, krait, Russell's viper, and saw-scaled viper).

Current ASV in India is not effective against humped pit viper (Option D): The polyvalent ASV available in India is ineffective against humped pit viper venom because it does not include antibodies specific to this species.

questions.text: Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient, who weighs 60 kg, using the provided serum electrolyte values: pH of 7.42, sodium (Na+) level of 120 mEq/L, and serum chloride (CI-) level of 90 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)720 mEq

Explanation:

  • Sodium Deficit Formula:
    • Sodium deficit = (Desired Na⁺ - Actual Na⁺) × Total Body Water (TBW)

Total Body Water (TBW):

  • TBW = 0.6 × Body Weight(for males)
  • = 0.5 x Body Weight(for females)

TBW for this patient: 0.6 × 60 kg = 36 litres

Desired Sodium Increase:

  • The target increase in serum sodium = 140 mEq/L - 120 mEq/L = 20 mEq/L

Sodium Deficit Calculation:

  • Sodium deficit = 20 mEq/L × 36 L = 720mEq

 

Safe Increase in Sodium:

  • In acute symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures, an initial rapid correction of 4-6 mEq/L in the first few hours is recommended to stabilize neurological symptoms.
  • The total correction should not exceed 8-12 mEq/L in the first 24 hours to avoid complications such as osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: A surgeon performs a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient. Despite adequate precautions, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. Under which of the following principles will the doctor not be held responsible for this act?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Medical Maloccurrence

Explanation:

  • This incident represents a medical maloccurrence because the complication arose from an unavoidable risk associated with the surgery, despite the surgeon providing quality care and obtaining informed consent.

Medical Maloccurrence

  • A less than ideal medical outcome not linked to the quality of care.
  • Types:
    • Anticipated medical/surgical complications (unavoidable risks).
    • Unpredictable complications (unavoidable).
    • Complications from informed patient-doctor decisions that seem inappropriate in hindsight.
  • Characteristics:
    • Often unrelated to the quality of care.
    • May occur despite good medical attention (e.g., idiosyncratic drug responses, nerve damage during surgery).

Incorrect Options:

Novus Actus Interveniens (Unrelated Intervening Action) (Option A):

  • This refers to an event that breaks the chain of causation from the original negligent act.
  • Negligence Element: Requires proof of negligence to establish a break in causation.
  • Often applied in incidents like leaving surgical instruments inside a patient.
  • Pleas are rarely accepted by courts.
  • It is not applicable here, as there is no intervening act causing the injury.

Doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitur (Option C):

  • Means "the thing speaks for itself"; Used when negligence is obvious.
  • Expert Evidence: Patients don’t need to prove negligence through expert testimony; the burden shifts to the doctor to prove innocence.
  • Conditions:
    • Injury would not have occurred without negligence.
    • The doctor had exclusive control over the treatment or instrument causing injury.
    • The patient was not contributory to negligence.
  • Examples:
    • Blood transfusion errors (infected blood, mismatches).
    • Failure to administer necessary vaccines.
    • Overprescribing medication.
    • Wrong-site surgeries.
    • Leaving surgical instruments inside the patient.
    • Failing to remove swabs, leading to complications.
    • Prolonged splinting causing loss of use of a limb.

However, in this case, ureteral injury is a known risk of hysterectomy, so it does not inherently indicate negligence.

Physician error (Option D): Physician error refers to a deviation from the standard of care. If the injury resulted from a genuine error or lack of skill, the doctor could be held responsible under this principle.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is not suitable for managing a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Streptokinase

Explanation:

  • In a patient with Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), streptokinase is not typically used for treatment.
  • Streptokinase belongs to the class of fibrinolytic agents and is commonly used for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) to dissolve blood clots causing the blockage in the coronary arteries. However, in NSTEMI, the underlying mechanism is often different, and the management approach focuses on antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation rather than fibrinolysis.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS:

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

 

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin (Option A)
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel, Prasugrel (Option B, D)

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management

  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

questions.text: What is the penalty for causing the death of a patient due to the use of counterfeit medication/spurious drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Life imprisonment

Explanation:

  • Under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 (Section 27A and 27B), if a patient dies due to the use of counterfeit/spurious drugs, the penalty includes life imprisonment and a fine of at least ₹10 lakhs or three times the value of the confiscated drugs, whichever is higher.

Counterfeit drugs:

  • Illegal.
  • Given to cheat or harm a person.
  • These drugs do not have the same therapeutic effect as genuine drugs and may lead to treatment failure.
  • Counterfeit drugs are not subjected to proper quality control.
  • People making illegal drugs are punished or jailed.

Types

Description

Example

Spurious Drugs

Have no active ingredient
  • 500 mg paracetamol tablet → when checked, it contains no paracetamol in it.
  • Made by illegal people other than the manufacturer to copy the drug.

Misbranded Drugs

Low-quality drugs
  • 500 mg tablet → when checked, it contains only 200 mg.
  • Made by the same manufacturer to increase profit.

Adulterated Drugs

Addition of harmful or unwanted excipients
  • Cough syrup made in India containing ethylene glycol → when checked, GMP guidelines do not approve these substances.
  • Ethylene glycol is harmful and not approved as an excipient by GMP.

questions.text: Which of the following are not included in the components of the MELD (2016) score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Albumin

Explanation:

  • Albumin is included in the calculation of the PELD (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) and not the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score.

MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score:

  • Predicts prognosis in chronic liver disease
  • It was developed to predict 3-month mortality in patients after TIPSS (transjugular portosystemic shunt)
  • Used in UNOS (United Nations Organ Sharing Network) to determine priority for liver transplantation.
  • Most patients with low MELD scores (less than 15) do not benefit from transplantation
  • Score: 6 - 40

Components:

  • Creatinine (Option D)
  • Bilirubin (Option A)
  • INR (Option B)

PELD (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) Score:

  • Used to determine priority for children awaiting liver transplantation
  • Components:
    • Nutrition
    • Age
    • Bilirubin
    • INR
    • Albumin

questions.text: In the given acid-base nomogram diagram, areas marked A and D indicated which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

A - Acute respiratory acidosis occurs when there is an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) in the blood due to inadequate ventilation. This can be caused by conditions such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or airway obstruction.

D - Acute respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in PaCO2 in the blood due to excessive ventilation. It can be caused by hyperventilation due to anxiety, fever, or high altitude.

 

Acid-base disorders

Simple acid-base disorders and their compensatory mechanisms:

  • Primary respiratory disturbances (changes in PaCO₂) lead to metabolic compensation (changes in [HCO₃⁻]).
  • Primary metabolic disturbances (changes in [HCO₃⁻]) lead to respiratory compensation (changes in PaCO₂).
  • Compensation moves pH toward normal, but typically does not fully correct it, except for chronic respiratory alkalosis, which may restore normal pH.
  • Metabolic acidosis (e.g., from ketoacidosis or lactic acidosis) lowers [HCO₃⁻] and extracellular pH, triggers ventilation (lowers PaCO₂) to compensate.
  • Winter’s equation predicts expected PaCO₂ in metabolic acidosis:
  • PaCO₂= (1.5×[HCO3−]) + 8 ± 2
    • Example: If [HCO₃⁻] = 12 mmol/L, expected PaCO₂ ≈ 26 mmHg ± 2
    • If PaCO₂ is <24 mmHg or >28 mmHg, a mixed disorder (e.g., metabolic acidosis + respiratory alkalosis/acidosis) is likely to be present.
    • Compensation direction:
    • Metabolic disorders: PaCO₂ moves in same direction as [HCO₃⁻].
    • Respiratory disorders: [HCO₃⁻] moves in same direction as PaCO₂.

Mixed acid-base disorders and the use of an acid-base nomogram:

  • Opposing Changes Indicate a Mixed Disorder:
    • If PaCO₂ and [HCO₃⁻] move in opposite directions (one increases while the other decreases), a mixed acid-base disorder is present.
    • Example: PaCO₂ increases (respiratory acidosis) while [HCO₃⁻] decreases (metabolic acidosis) → Mixed acidosis.
  • Acid-Base Nomogram:
    • An acid-base nomogram is a graphical tool used to analyze and interpret acid-base disturbances in the body. It helps in determining the primary acid-base disorder and assessing compensatory responses.
    • The nomogram typically consists of a graph with axes representing the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2 ) and the bicarbonate (HCO3-) concentration.
    • The diagonal lines on the graph represent different levels of blood pH.
    • The shaded areas represent the 95% confidence limits for compensation in simple disorders.
    • Values within the shaded area do not rule out a mixed disorder, since overlapping conditions might mimic a different disorder.

  • Equations vs Nomogram:
     
    • The nomogram is useful but not a substitute for calculations.
    • Equations like Winter’s equation provide a more precise assessment of compensation.

Disorder

Prediction of Compensation

Range of Values (pH, HCO₃⁻, PaCO₂)

Metabolic Acidosis

PaCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2 /

PaCO₂ ↓ 1.25 mmHg per mmol/L ↓ in HCO₃⁻ /

PaCO₂ = HCO₃⁻ + 15

Low, Low, Low

Metabolic Alkalosis

PaCO₂ ↑ 0.75 mmHg per mmol/L ↑ in HCO₃⁻

PaCO₂ ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in HCO₃⁻

PaCO₂ = HCO₃⁻ + 15

High, High, High

Respiratory Alkalosis

Acute: HCO₃⁻ ↓ 0.2 mmol/L per mmHg ↓ in PaCO₂ Chronic: HCO₃⁻ ↓ 0.4 mmol/L per mmHg ↓ in PaCO₂

High, Low, Low

Respiratory Acidosis

Acute: HCO₃⁻ ↑ 0.1 mmol/L per mmHg ↑ in PaCO₂

Chronic: HCO₃⁻ ↑ 0.4 mmol/L per mmHg ↑ in PaCO₂

Low, High, High

questions.text:
Match the following poisons with their probable mechanism of action:


	
		
			
			A. Zinc chloride
			
			
			1. Abortifacient
			
		
		
			
			B. Chloral hydrate
			
			
			2. Irritant
			
		
		
			
			C. Quinine
			
			
			3. Corrosive
			
		
		
			
			D. Potassium carbonate
			
			
			4. Stupefying
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

Zinc chloride (A-2): Acts as an irritant due to its caustic effect on tissues.

Chloral hydrate (B-4): Causes stupefaction due to its sedative-hypnotic action.

Quinine (C-1): Known for its abortifacient property as it can stimulate uterine contractions.


Potassium carbonate (D-3): Functions as a corrosive agent due to its strong alkali nature.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was brought to the ER after an assault with a sharp axe. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chop wound

Explanation:

  • The injury from the scenario is suggestive of a chop wound.
  • A chop wound is a deep injury caused by a heavy, sharp object like an axe.
  • It combines features of both an incised wound (sharp edges) and a lacerated wound (underlying tissue damage and crushing effect).

Chop wounds/ Slash wounds

  • These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force.
  • It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Weapons used

  • Hatchet
  • Axe
  • Sword
  • Broad heavy knife
  • Chopper
  • Saber
  • Meat cleaver

Features of the wound
  • The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe).
  • It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone.
  • Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade.
  • Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs.

Medicolegal importance

  • Most injuries are homicidal.
  • Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries).
  • Rarely suicidal.
  • Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack.

 

Chop wound on forehead from a propeller accident


Incorrect Options:

Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is caused by a sharp-edged object, such as a knife or blade, and is characterized by clean-cut edges.

Lacerated wound (Option C): Lacerated wounds are caused by blunt force trauma, resulting in irregular edges. An axe typically causes more defined sharp edges, making it a chop wound rather than a laceration.

Abrasion (Option D): Abrasions are superficial injuries caused by friction or scraping against a rough surface, which is not applicable in the case of an axe assault.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with an injury sustained during a football match after being tackled by an opponent. As the casualty medical officer, how would you describe the wound in the case sheet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laceration

Explanation:

The above image and scenario are suggestive of a laceration

  • Laceration is the tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, or internal organs due to a shearing or crushing force from a blunt impact over a broad area.
  • When blunt force causes severe bruising and damage to deeper tissues, it is referred to as a crush injury.

Characteristics

  • Irregular Margins: Ragged, uneven edges with pointed or blunt ends, often showing small tears.
  • Swallow Tails: Tearing at the ends of lacerations, diverging.
  • Bruising: Seen around the wound, more pronounced in areas impacted at an angle or with downward force.
  • Tissue Bridges: Deeper tissues are unevenly torn, leaving nerve, vessel, and connective tissue bridges.
  • Hair Damage: Crushed hair bulbs; hair and skin tags may be embedded in the wound.
  • Hemorrhage: Less severe bleeding as arteries are crushed and torn irregularly, retracting and allowing blood to clot.
  • Soiling: Debris like mud, wood splinters, sand, glass, or hair can become embedded, carrying medico-legal significance.
  • Wound Gaping: Impact from an angle causes tearing on the opposite side and abrasion on the impact side, leading to gaping.

Incorrect Options:

Incised wounds (Option A): They have clean, smooth edges and do not show the uneven tearing or bruising present in this case.

Abrasions (Option B): They involve superficial skin damage and typically lack deep tissue involvement and significant bruising.

Bruise (Option D): A bruise (contusion) is caused by blunt trauma, leading to subcutaneous bleeding without a break in the skin.

Explanation:

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient presented to the emergency room with symptoms of palpitation, dizziness. On examination pulse is 180 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 70 mmHg systolic. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with a regular heart rate. What should be the next course of action in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DC cardioversion

Explanation:

  • In this patient, immediate cardioversion is the most appropriate next step in the management.

 

DC cardioversion

  • Electrical cardioversion (DC cardioversion) is used to terminate organized arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation (AF) or ventricular tachycardia (VT). It is the treatment of choice for unstable tachyarrhythmias.
  • The electric current interrupts the arrhythmia, causing a brief asystole, usually followed by the return of sinus rhythm.
  • It is usually performed as an elective procedure under general anesthesia.
  • The shock is delivered immediately after the R wave to avoid triggering ventricular fibrillation (VF), which may occur if applied during ventricular repolarization (T wave).
  • High-energy shocks may cause chest wall pain post-procedure.
  • If there is no urgency, it is best to start with a lower-energy shock (around 50 joules) and increase if necessary.

 

Adenosine (Option B) is commonly used for the acute termination of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) episodes. However, it is not the preferred initial treatment for a patient with signs of hemodynamic instability and low blood pressure. Adenosine can cause a transient period of asystole when administered, which can further compromise the patient's blood pressure.

Valsalva Maneuver (Option C) involves straining against a closed glottis, can be attempted as a non-invasive method to terminate certain types of supraventricular tachycardias.

Verapamil (Option D) is a calcium channel blocker that can be effective in terminating certain types of supraventricular tachycardias, such as atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia.

questions.text: The medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fasciculus gracilis

Explanation:

  • The medial lemniscus is a continuation of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus, which are part of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway. This pathway carries sensory information related to fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the lower body (fasciculus gracilis) and upper body (fasciculus cuneatus) to the brain.
  • The fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus are composed of ascending sensory fibers that originate from the dorsal root ganglia in the spinal cord.

 

Dorsal Column (Posterior Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway):

 

Category

Details

Components

Fasciculus Gracilis: Carries sensory information from the lower limbs (Option C)

Fasciculus Cuneatus: Carries sensory information from the upper limbs

Sensations

Pressure

Tactile discrimination

Vibration

Conscious Proprioception

Stereognosis

Neuronal Pathway

1st Order Neuron: Located in the dorsal root ganglion

2nd Order Neuron: Located in the medulla oblongata

3rd Order Neuron: Located in the thalamus

Spinothalamic tract (Option A): The spinothalamic tract is a separate pathway that carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations from the body to the thalamus.

Spinocerebellar tract (Option B): The spinocerebellar tracts are involved in carrying proprioceptive information from the spinal cord to the cerebellum, which helps in coordinating and fine-tuning motor movements.

Spinotectal tract (Option C): The spinotectal tract is involved in conveying sensory information related to pain and temperature from the body to the superior colliculus in the midbrain, which plays a role in orienting visual and auditory responses to stimuli.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC (Medico-Legal Case) is brought by the police. The deceased has the following appearance and was declared brought dead. What is the likely cause of death before sending the body for postmortem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Drowning

Explanation:

  • The image is suggestive of Drowning. Key findings in drowning cases are as follows;

Signs of Antemortem Drowning:

  • External Signs: Foam at the mouth/nose, Washerwoman skin, Cyanosis.
  • Internal Signs:
    • Lungs: Over-distended, heavy, and waterlogged,
    • Mucus: Sticky mucus in airways due to fluid inhalation.
  • Diatoms: Microscopic algae in internal organs (bone marrow), indicating water inhalation.
  • Paltauf’s spots: Subpleural hemorrhages caused by lung over-expansion.

Incorrect Options:

Hanging (Option B): Hanging typically shows signs like:

  • Ligature marks on the neck, running obliquely and above the thyroid cartilage.
  • Petechial hemorrhages in the conjunctiva.
  • Absence of water-related findings like froth or washerwoman's hands.

Strangulation (Option C): Strangulation presents with:

  • Horizontal ligature marks.
  • Extensive neck bruising and petechiae.
  • No water-related findings.


Traumatic asphyxia (Option D): Traumatic asphyxia is caused by severe compression of the chest, leading to cyanosis and petechial hemorrhages, without water-related findings.

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate approach for a patient experiencing chest pain for the past 3 hours, where an ECG shows ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin with heparin

Explanation:

  • As the patient presented within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain, which suggests an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and the ECG findings of ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion are consistent with myocardial ischemia..
  • Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet aggregation and Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents the formation and propagation of blood clots. It is administered promptly to patients suspected of having ACS to minimize ongoing thrombosis.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS:

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management

  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

 

PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) (Option A) is a preferred treatment option for patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Thrombolysis with alteplase (Option B) is primarily indicated for patients with STEMI who present within a specific time window and are not candidates for primary PCI.

While arrhythmias can be a complication of ACS, prophylactic treatment for arrhythmias (Option C) is not the primary management strategy in the acute phase. The focus initially is on addressing the underlying ischemia and preventing further thrombosis through antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a patient who has significant abdominal swelling and laboratory analysis of the fluid obtained through paracentesis reveals SAAG <1.1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • Among the given options, only in tuberculosis SAAG score will be < 1.1 mg/dl, all others will have SAAG >1.1mg/dl.
  • Congestive heart failure (Option A) can also lead to the development of ascites. However, in this, the SAAG is usually greater than 1.1 g/dL.
  • SAAG is usually greater than 1.1 g/dL in myxoedema (Option B)and Budd Chiari syndrome (Option C).

Interpretations of SAAG:

  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL: Portal hypertension (ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids)
    • Ascitic protein level ≥2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are normal (allows passage of protein)
    • Ascitic protein level <2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are damaged and scarred (no passage of protein)
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL: Ascites is not related to portal hypertension.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Midbrain

Explanation:

  • The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is one of the three major fiber tracts that connect the cerebellum with the rest of the brain. It is located on the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.
  • The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle refers to the crossing over of its fibers from one side of the brainstem to the other. This decussation occurs at the level of the midbrain, specifically in the region called the upper midbrain tegmentum.

Cerebellar Peduncle:
It connects the cerebellum to the brainstem.

  • Superior cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the midbrain.
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the pons.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the cerebellum to the medulla.

Pons (Option A): While the pons is involved in the transmission of various neural signals, the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle does not occur at this level.

Diencephalon (Option C): The diencephalon, housing the thalamus and hypothalamus, lies above the midbrain. The superior cerebellar peduncle's decussation doesn't happen within the diencephalon.

Medulla (Option D): While the medulla is involved in various vital functions, including cardiovascular and respiratory control, the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle does not occur at the level of the medulla.

questions.text: Identify the injury depicted in the image provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Shot gun wound

Explanation:

  • The image shown depicts a typical pattern of injury caused by a shotgun. The appearance of multiple pellet or shot holes, irregular wound edges, and tissue destruction is characteristic of a shotgun wound.

Type of shotgun wounds

Type of wound

Circular

Circular

Present around the margins and even inside the wound.

Images

Incorrect Options:

Tattooing (Option B): Tattooing refers to pinpoint marks caused by unburned gunpowder particles embedding in the skin around the entry wound, typically seen in close-range firearm injuries. While tattooing can be a feature of shotgun wounds, it is not the primary injury type depicted.

Arsenic poisoning (Option C): Arsenic poisoning presents with systemic signs like Mee's lines (white lines on nails), gastrointestinal distress, and multi-organ failure. No external wound patterns are associated.

Graze wound (Option D): A graze wound occurs when a projectile or object scrapes the skin surface, leaving an elongated abrasion.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sympathetic chain

Explanation:

  • The carotid sheath is a fibrous connective tissue structure located in the neck. It contains several important structures, including the carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and 10th cranial nerve (vagus nerve).
  • Sympathetic chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, is not a content of the carotid sheath. The sympathetic chain runs alongside the vertebral column and is responsible for carrying sympathetic nerve fibers.

Carotid Sheath: Condensation of the connective tissue around the great vessels of the neck, forming a tubular sheet of fascia.

 

Contents
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve

Anatomical Details
  • The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries.
  • The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels.

Anteriorly
  • The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia.

Posteriorly
  • The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia.

 

Carotid artery (Option B): The carotid artery, specifically the common carotid artery, is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to the head and neck. It is a content of the carotid sheath.

Internal jugular vein (Option C): The internal jugular vein, running parallel to the carotid artery, drains blood from the brain, face, and neck, and is contained within the carotid sheath.

10th cranial nerve (vagus nerve) (Option D): The vagus nerve, or the 10th cranial nerve, innervates numerous thoracic and abdominal organs. In the neck, it travels within the carotid sheath.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man was found dead at home and brought to the mortuary by the police. Upon examination, certain findings were noted. What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Strangulation by ligature

Explanation:

  • Strangulation by ligature is typically characterized by:
    • Horizontal ligature marks on the neck, often at or above the level of the thyroid cartilage.
    • Deep bruising around the neck area, often due to the tight ligature.
    • Petechial hemorrhages in the eyes, face, and skin above the ligature mark.
    • Absence of other signs of hanging, such as the upward traction on the neck.
    • No evidence of a fall or suspension, which distinguishes it from hanging.

Causes of Death in Ligature Strangulation:

  1. Asphyxia
  2. Cerebral anoxia
  3. Vagal inhibition
  4. Cervical Vertebrae Fracture

Postmortem Findings:

1. External Examination:

Finding

Description

Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva.
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature.
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.

Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.

Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

2. Internal Examination:

  • On dissection- Contusion and haemorrhage- of tissue, muscles of the neck, tonsils and glands.
  • Fracture of the thyroid cartilage is commonly seen.
  • Fracture of the hyoid bone is not very common as it is usually at or below the level of the thyroid.

Incorrect Options:

Hanging (Option B): Hanging is characterized by:

  • Oblique ligature marks typically at or below the thyroid cartilage.
  • Signs of suspension or a fall from height.
  • Petechial hemorrhages and tongue protrusion.
  • Possible fractures of the cervical spine or hyoid bone.
    Hanging marks are different in appearance from those caused by strangulation with a ligature.

 

Throttling (Option C): Throttling involves manual strangulation and is characterized by:

  • Irregular ligature marks or fingerprints on the neck.
  • Bruising around the neck due to the pressure applied by hands.
  • No horizontal ligature marks like in strangulation by a ligature.

 

Drowning (Option D): Drowning typically shows:

  • Water in the lungs and froth at the mouth.
  • Washerwoman’s hands and mud in the respiratory tract.
  • Absence of ligature marks or any other signs of manual strangulation.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not a use of enteric-coated drugs?

a) Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity

b) Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs

c) Prolongs the half-life of the drug

d) Deliver drugs distal to the stomach
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - C

Enteric-coated drugs are primarily used to:

  • Protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity (a), ensuring they pass through the stomach without degradation.
  • Protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects (b) & prevent gastric distress and vomiting.
  • Deliver drugs distal to the stomach (d), releasing them in the intestine.
  • Minimizing first pass metabolism
  • To provide a delayed-release component for repeat action

questions.text: What structure develops from the region labeled as "A" in the model of embryological heart development?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Infundibulum

Explanation:

  • In the embryological development of the heart, the area marked as "A" corresponds to the outflow tract of the developing heart. This outflow tract gives rise to several structures, including the infundibulum. The infundibulum is a conical structure located at the outflow of the right ventricle. It connects the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery and directs blood flow from the heart to the lungs.

Formation of Heart Tubes:

  • The endothelial heart tube is derived from the splanchnopleuric mesoderm, located near the pericardial cavity.
  • Initially, the heart appears as right and left endothelial heart tubes.
  • These tubes fuse to form a single heart tube.
  • The heart tube has 5 dilatations, which are:
    • Truncus arteriosus
    • Bulbus cordis
    • Primitive ventricle
    • Primitive atrium
    • Sinus venosus
  • Sinus venosus is located at the caudal (venous) end of the primitive heart tube.
    • It consists of a body with two prolongations known as the right and left horns.
    • Right horn: Forms smooth part of the right atrium (sinus venarum).
    • Left horn: Forms coronary sinus.
    • Each horn receives blood from three veins:
      • Vitelline vein
      • Umbilical vein
      • Common cardinal vein
  • Bulbus cordis is the cranial most part of the developing heart tube.
    • Forms outflow (smooth) parts of the right ventricle (conus arteriosus) and left ventricle (aortic vestibule).
  • Primitive ventricle: Forms inflow (rough) parts of both ventricles.
  • Primitive atrium: Forms trabeculated part of the right and left atrium.
  • Truncus arteriosus: Forms ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.

Formation of Transverse Pericardial Sinus:

  • Heart Tube Folding: Brings the arterial and venous ends closer together.
  • Disappearance of the dorsal mesocardium creates the transverse sinus of the pericardium.
  • Parietal and visceral layers of the serous pericardium become continuous at the arterial and venous ends of the heart.
  • Pericardium forms two tubes:
    • One enclosing the aorta and pulmonary trunk.
    • Other enclosing the SVC, IVC, and four pulmonary veins.
  • Two tubes are separated by the transverse sinus of the pericardium.

Atria (Option A): The atria develop from the primitive heart tube, specifically from the regions known as the primitive atrium and sinus venosus.

Left ventricle (Option B): The left ventricle develops from the primitive heart tube and forms the main pumping chamber of the heart that sends oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation.

Interventricular septum (Option D): The interventricular septum develops from the fusion of several components during heart development.

questions.text: What advice would you provide to prevent the transmission of active genital warts in a female patient with a history of recurrence, despite her husband not being affected by it?

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don’t involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Don’t involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

Explanation:

  • Genital warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and can be transmitted through sexual contact. When a female patient presents with active genital warts and a history of recurrence, it is important to provide appropriate advice to prevent transmission to her partner.
  • The most effective measure to prevent transmission of genital warts is to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present. This is because the virus is most contagious and easily transmitted when the warts are actively present

Treatment for genital warts involves both individual and partner management

Individual Treatment:

  • Topical Medications: Various topical medications can be prescribed to treat genital warts. These include:
  • Imiquimod cream/Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) or bichloroacetic acid (BCA): These acids are applied directly to the warts to destroy them.
  • Surgical Procedures
  • These procedures include:
    • Cryotherapy
    • Electrocautery
    • Surgical excision

Partner Management:

  • It is important to inform the partner about the presence of genital warts so that they can also seek appropriate medical evaluation and treatment if necessary.
  • It is best to avoid sexual activity, especially during active wart outbreaks, to prevent transmission to the partner.


Incorrect Options:

Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient (Option A): Prophylactic treatments such as topical creams or vaccines are typically used for individuals who have not yet contracted the virus or to prevent future outbreaks.

Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband (Option B): Antiviral medications are primarily used for the treatment of active infections or to reduce the severity and duration of outbreaks, but they do not provide long-term protection against transmission.

Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present (Option C): While antiviral medications can be used to treat active genital warts and reduce the duration of outbreaks, using them solely when active lesions are present is not the most effective approach to prevent transmission.

questions.text:
Which of the following side effects are likely to be observed when a patient already taking metoprolol is prescribed verapamil?

a) Bradycardia with Av Block
b) Torsades De Pointes
c) Tachycardia
d) Ventricular Fibrillation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - a only

Metoprolol (a beta-blocker) and verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) negatively affect heart rate and AV conduction. When used together, they can cause bradycardia (slow heart rate) and AV block, which can be dangerous.

Torsades de pointes (Option B) is a type of ventricular tachycardia with a distinct ECG pattern. Although both metoprolol and verapamil can influence cardiac conduction, their combination is not typically linked to the development of torsades de pointes.

Tachycardia (Option C): Both metoprolol and verapamil have negative chronotropic effects, meaning they lower the heart rate. As a result, combining these drugs is unlikely to cause tachycardia (an increased heart rate).

Ventricular fibrillation (Option D) is a severe, life-threatening arrhythmia marked by rapid, irregular ventricular contractions. While both metoprolol and verapamil affect heart conduction, their combination is not commonly associated with ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given Image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extension and lateral rotation

Explanation:

  • The muscle attached to the area marked in the given image is the gluteus maximus. The gluteus maximus is the largest muscle in the gluteal region and is primarily responsible for extending the hip joint, which means it helps to move the thigh backward. This action is commonly referred to as hip extension.
  • Additionally, the gluteus maximus also assists in lateral rotation of the hip joint. Lateral rotation refers to the outward rotation of the thigh away from the midline of the body.

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation:

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

 

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)

 

 

Extension

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)

  • Tensor fasciae latae

  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)

  • Tensor fasciae latae
