  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

Flexion and medial rotation (Option A): Flexion of the hip joint involves bringing the thigh forward, towards the abdomen. The gluteus maximus acts opposite to this motion by extending the hip, so it is not involved in hip flexion. Medial rotation refers to the inward rotation of the thigh towards the midline of the body, which is also not a primary action of the gluteus maximus.

Adduction and lateral rotation (Option B): Adduction involves bringing the thigh towards the midline of the body. The gluteus maximus is not directly involved in hip adduction. Lateral rotation is the correct action associated with the gluteus maximus, as explained earlier.

Abduction and medial rotation (Option C): Abduction refers to moving the thigh away from the midline of the body, which is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Medial rotation, as mentioned earlier, is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus.

questions.text: What could be the potential cause of the following lesions in a gardener who has a history of thorn pricks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sporothrix schenckii

Explanation:

  • The lesions described in the question, following a thorn prick, are suggestive of a condition known as sporotrichosis or rose gardener's disease.
  • The characteristic feature of sporotrichosis is the distribution of the lesions along the lymphatic vessels. The infection typically starts as a small, painless bump or nodule at the site of the inoculation, and it then spreads along the lymphatic vessels, forming a chain of nodules or ulcers.

Sporotrichosis

  • Sporotrichosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, commonly known as “rose gardener’s disease.” It occurs through trauma-induced inoculation from soil, plants, or organic matter.

Pathophysiology

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that exists as a mold in the environment and yeast in human tissue.
  • The fungus spreads via lymphatics, causing characteristic nodular lymphangitis.

Features

  • Cutaneous (most common):
    • Painless nodules and ulcers along lymphatic channels (lymphocutaneous form).
  • Pulmonary:
    • Chronic cough, fever, weight loss (inhalation exposure).
  • Disseminated (rare, immunocompromised patients):
    • Systemic involvement affecting bones, joints, and CNS.

Investigations & Diagnosis

  • Culture (gold standard): Grows Sporothrix schenckii on Sabouraud’s agar.
  • Microscopy: Shows cigar-shaped yeast on tissue samples.
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation with fungal elements.

Treatment

  • First-line: Itraconazole (100-200 mg/day) for cutaneous cases.
  • Severe/disseminated cases: Amphotericin B, followed by itraconazole.
  • Potassium iodide (older treatment): Still used in some regions.

Incorrect Options:

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option A): It is not the causative agent for the described presentation of lesions following a thorn prick.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C): Strongyloides stercoralis does not typically present with the specific lesion distribution described in the question.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option D): Staphylococcus aureus is not the primary causative agent for the described presentation. Sporothrix schenckii is more commonly associated with the development of sporotrichosis in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Middle meningeal artery

Explanation:

The area marked by the arrow corresponds to the pterion, where several skull bones meet. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs nearby. It supplies blood to the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, passing through the pterion and branching out to supply surrounding structures.

Pterion:

Located at the anterolateral fontanelle and is formed by the union of

    • Frontal bone
    • Parietal bone
    • Squamous temporal bones &
    • Greater wing of the sphenoid.

  • At birth, this area is filled with a membrane, which typically closes by around 2 months of age, though it can sometimes be delayed until 6 months.
  • The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery runs beneath the Pterion and Stem of lateral sulcus .
  • Injury to this area can result in extradural or epidural haemorrhage.
  • The pterion is a frequent location for trephination (creating an opening in the skull) during surgical procedures.

Internal carotid artery (Option A): The internal carotid artery is crucial for brain blood supply but doesn't closely pass by the pterion.

Anterior cerebral artery (Option C): The anterior cerebral artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery, provides blood to the frontal lobes and medial brain regions, but it doesn't closely approach the pterion.

Deep temporal artery (Option D): The deep temporal arteries, stemming from the maxillary artery, nourish the temporal head region. Although they are nearby, they don't directly approach the pterion.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 40-year-old woman who experienced fever and joint pain, and subsequently developed a lesion on her nose a few days after taking NSAIDs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chikungunya

Explanation:

  • Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, joint pain, muscle pain, headache, and rash.
  • The development of pigmentation on the nose after taking NSAIDs can occur in chikungunya. Other symptoms, such as joint pain and fever support this diagnosis.
  • Some other dermatological features associated with chikungunya include:
    • Maculopapular rash: small, raised bumps on the skin. The rash can appear on the trunk, limbs, and face. It is usually non-itchy and may be accompanied by redness or discoloration of the skin.
    • Erythema multiforme-like rash: characterized by target-shaped or iris-like lesions with concentric rings of color on the skin. It typically affects the extremities, including the hands and feet.
    • Vesiculobullous lesions: Rarely, chikungunya can cause the formation of fluid-filled blisters or bullae on the skin.
    • Desquamation: After the initial rash subsides, some individuals with chikungunya may experience desquamation


Incorrect Options:

Dengue (Option A): The rash in dengue is often described as maculopapular or petechial and can appear on the trunk, limbs, and face. The symptoms and rash pattern associated with dengue differ from the presentation described in the question, making it an incorrect option.

Melasma (Option C): Melasma is typically associated with hormonal changes, sun exposure, and genetic factors. The lesions in melasma are symmetrical and do not usually present as a single lesion on the nose as shown in the image. Therefore, melasma is an incorrect option.

Fixed drug eruption (Option D): Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug reaction characterized by recurring skin lesions at the same site each time the causative drug is taken. The lesions typically appear as well-demarcated, round or oval patches with dusky red or violaceous coloration. While fixed drug eruptions can occur after taking certain medications, they are not typically associated with the use of NSAIDs alone.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be combined with rosuvastatin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Clarithromycin

  • Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that can inhibit the liver enzyme CYP3A4, which is involved in the metabolism of various medications, including rosuvastatin.
  • This inhibition can result in higher levels of rosuvastatin in the bloodstream, increasing the risk of side effects such as muscle damage (myopathy) or severe muscle breakdown (rhabdomyolysis).
  • As a result, combining rosuvastatin with clarithromycin should be avoided unless the benefits outweigh the risks.
  • If an antibiotic is needed, alternatives like azithromycin, which does not significantly affect CYP3A4, may be considered.

Oxycodone (Option A): There is no significant interaction between rosuvastatin and oxycodone. These medications can generally be used together without the need for special precautions or dosage adjustments.

Adalimumab (Option C), used to treat inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease, does not have a known significant interaction with rosuvastatin. These medications can be used together safely.

Rivaroxaban (Option D), an anticoagulant, does not interact significantly with rosuvastatin. These medications can be taken together without any specific concerns.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath. Upon auscultation, the physician detects a pan systolic murmur that is best heard at the right side of the heart. The murmur radiates to the axilla and is louder during inspiration. The patient denies any history of fever, chest pain, or recent infections. What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient's condition based on the described findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tricuspid Regurgitation

Explanation:

  • Tricuspid regurgitation is characterized by a pan systolic murmur heard best along the right side of the heart and it radiates to the right of the sternum. Additionally, tricuspid regurgitation is often secondary to other conditions affecting the right side of the heart, such as pulmonary hypertension or right heart failure.
  • The characteristics of a pan systolic murmur heard at the right side of the heart and radiating to the axilla, along with the absence of signs of aortic stenosis, mitral valve prolapse, and ventricular septal defect, point toward tricuspid regurgitation as the most likely diagnosis in this case. It's important to consider the entire clinical picture and potentially perform further tests (e.g., echocardiography) to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the condition.

 

Aortic Stenosis (Option A) Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids, best heard at the right upper sternal border
Mitral Valve Prolapse (Option B) Late systolic murmur is best heard at the apex, not a pan systolic murmur. Typically preceded by a non-ejection click, and intensity and duration increases with maneuvers that decrease ventricular volume.
Ventricular Septal Defect (Option C) Harsh, holosystolic murmur heard, best at the left lower sternal border, as blood flows from the higher-pressure left ventricle to the lower-pressure right ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Opponens pollicis

Explanation:

  • The opponens pollicis muscle is indeed attached to the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. This muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium and scaphoid bones in the wrist. Its tendon inserts onto the palmar surface of the first metacarpal bone. The opponens pollicis muscle functions to oppose the thumb, allowing for its opposition to the other fingers, a key movement for precision grip.

Flexor pollicis brevis

Abductor Pollicis Longus (Option A): The abductor pollicis longus muscle abducts the thumb but doesn't directly attach to the palm side of the first metacarpal.

Palmar Interossei (Option B): While palmar interossei muscles are in the vicinity of the first metacarpal bone, they are not specifically attached to the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.

Flexor Pollicis Brevis (Option D): The flexor pollicis brevis muscle helps with thumb flexion and opposition but doesn't directly attach to the palm side of the first metacarpal.

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave:

A - ‘a’ wave

B - 1st heart sound

C - Rapid filling of ventricles

D - ‘t’ wave
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ABDC

The correct sequence after the P wave is as follows:

  • A. The 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. It occurs during atrial systole when the atria contract to push blood into the ventricles.
  • B. The 1st heart sound, also known as S1, is the closure of the atrioventricular (AV) valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) at the beginning of ventricular systole. It marks the onset of ventricular contraction.
  • D. The 't' wave is a repolarization phase of the ventricles. It represents the relaxation and resetting of the ventricles after contraction.
  • C. After the 't' wave, the ventricles enter the diastole phase, during which they passively fill with blood from the atria. This is known as rapid ventricular filling.

 

Therefore, the correct sequence is ABDC: 'a' wave, 1st heart sound, rapid filling of ventricles, and 't' wave.

 

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

 

Respiration Influence:

  • Venous pressure decreases during inspiration due to negative intrathoracic pressure, and rises during expiration.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bleomycin

Explanation:

  • Flagellate dermatitis, also known as "flagellate erythema," is a distinctive skin reaction that can occur as a side effect of certain medications. Among the given options, the most commonly associated drug with flagellate dermatitis is Bleomycin, which is an antineoplastic medication used in the treatment of various cancers.
  • Flagellate dermatitis typically appears as linear or streak-like red or brownish patches on the skin, resembling the marks left by a whip or a scratch. It usually occurs on the trunk, extremities, or face and is believed to be an idiosyncratic reaction to Bleomycin.
  • Bleomycin-induced flagellate dermatitis is thought to be related to the drug's ability to induce the release of inflammatory mediators, resulting in the characteristic skin reaction. It typically occurs within a few days to weeks after the administration of Bleomycin and tends to resolve spontaneously once the drug is discontinued.

 

Some common side effects associated with the use of Bleomycin:

Side Effect

Description

Pulmonary Toxicity

Bleomycin is known to cause lung damage, which can lead to pulmonary fibrosis and respiratory symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and decreased lung function.

Skin Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause skin reactions, including flagellate dermatitis (linear streaks on the skin), erythema (redness), and skin desquamation (peeling).

Mucosal Toxicity

Bleomycin can cause mucosal damage, resulting in mouth sores, sore throat, and inflammation of the oral and nasal mucosa.

Fever

Fever is a common side effect of Bleomycin treatment and can occur shortly after administration.

Hematologic Toxicity

Bleomycin can suppress bone marrow function, leading to decreased production of blood cells, including red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

Nail Changes

Bleomycin can cause nail abnormalities, including nail discoloration, brittle nails, and nail bed inflammation.

Allergic Reactions

Allergic reactions to Bleomycin can occur, ranging from mild rash to severe hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis.

 

Incorrrect Options:

Actinomycin (Option A): Actinomycin is an antibiotic medication used in chemotherapy. While it can cause various dermatological side effects, flagellate dermatitis is not commonly associated with Actinomycin use.

Mitomycin C (Option C): Mitomycin C is an antineoplastic medication used in the treatment of certain cancers. While it can cause skin reactions, flagellate dermatitis is not a recognized side effect commonly associated with Mitomycin C use.

Doxorubicin (Option D): Doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer. While it can cause skin-related side effects, flagellate dermatitis is not a well-known or commonly reported side effect of Doxorubicin use.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Foramen rotundum

Explanation:

Foramen Rotundum. The foramen rotundum is indeed located in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It is a rounded opening that lies in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, on the medial part of the infratemporal surface. The foramen rotundum serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (V2), which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

Foramen Ovale (Option B): The foramen ovale is a separate opening in the sphenoid bone, located posterior and slightly lateral to the foramen rotundum. It is larger and oval-shaped.

Vidian Canal (Option C): The vidian canal, or pterygoid canal, is a narrow bony passage in the sphenoid bone. It runs obliquely between the pterygopalatine fossa and the middle cranial fossa.

Foramen Spinosum (Option D): The foramen spinosum, a small opening, is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, positioned posteriorly and laterally to the foramen ovale.

questions.text: Which topical antifungal exhibits both anti-inflammatory properties and provides relief from itching?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Sertaconazole

  • Sertaconazole not only possesses antifungal properties but also has both anti-inflammatory and anti-pruritic (anti-itch) effects.
  • It works by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, a crucial component of fungal cell membranes, thereby disrupting the growth and replication of fungi.
  • It inhibits the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines from activated immune cells.
  • Its anti-inflammatory action helps alleviate redness, swelling, and other inflammatory symptoms.
  • Additionally, its anti-pruritic effect provides relief from itching, a common symptom of many fungal infections.

questions.text: What is not a characteristic feature of Wilson's disease?

choices.text: Presents before age 40 with liver disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) No Free radical injury

Explanation:

  • Free radical injury due to an excess of copper ions is seen in patients with Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease

  • Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder (Option A), usually presents before age 40 (Option D) with liver disease caused by the abnormal accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs. This results in elevated free copper levels, along with increased copper levels in the liver and urine, while serum ceruloplasmin levels are decreased.

Gene Affected:

  • The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene (Option C) on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase responsible for excreting copper from the liver into bile.

Pathogenesis:
 

Lab parameters of Wilson’s disease

Parameter

Change

Explanation

Free Copper

⬆️ Increased

Unbound copper elevated due to impaired binding.

Liver Copper

⬆️ Increased

Accumulation due to defective biliary excretion.

Urinary Copper

⬆️ Increased

Overflow from the liver leads to high excretion.

Total Copper

⬇️ Decreased

Mainly composed of ceruloplasmin-bound copper.

Serum Ceruloplasmin

⬇️ Decreased

Defective incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.

Its primary action is to adduct and internally rotate the arm, as in movements such as hugging or pressing the arms against the body. It does not play a significant role in raising the arm in an overhead position.

Serratus anterior (Option A): The serratus anterior muscle plays an important role in stabilizing and upwardly rotating the scapula during arm abduction.

Deltoid (Option B): The deltoid muscle, which is located on the shoulder, is a key muscle involved in the abduction of the arm.
