questions.text: A child presents to OPD with tense bullae over the torso. A biopsy of the lesion showed a subepidermal level of blistering and neutrophil infiltration. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dapsone

Explanation:

  • Based on the given information of a child presenting with tense bullae over the torso and a biopsy showing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, the most likely diagnosis is Bullous Pemphigoid.
  • The primary treatment for Bullous Pemphigoid is systemic immunosuppressive therapy, and Dapsone is one of the drugs of choice for this condition.

Mechanism of Action of Dapsone

  • Inhibits neutrophil chemotaxis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, reducing blister formation.
  • Suppresses inflammatory mediators, leading to decreased skin damage.

Indications in Subepidermal Autoimmune Bullous Diseases

  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis (DH) - First-line treatment
  • Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis (LABD) - Effective in most cases
  • Bullous Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (BSLE) - Used in resistant cases
  • Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA) - Occasionally used as adjunct therapy


Incorrect Options:

Rituximab (Option A): Rituximab can be used in some cases of autoimmune blistering disorders, it is not typically the drug of choice for Bullous Pemphigoid.

Cyclosporine (Option C): Cyclosporine it is not the first-line drug of choice.

Azathioprine (Option D): Azathioprine is usually reserved for cases that are refractory to first-line treatments or as a steroid-sparing agent. It is not the initial drug of choice.

questions.text: For a patient who has commenced lithium therapy, which of the following adverse effects should they be instructed to be vigilant for in order to detect any signs of toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vertigo and Diarrhoea

  • Lithium is commonly prescribed for treating bipolar disorder. While effective in managing mood symptoms, it is crucial to monitor for potential side effects, including signs of lithium toxicity.
  • A key feature of lithium toxicity is the occurrence of neurological and gastrointestinal disturbances. Vertigo, a spinning or dizzy sensation, is one such neurological symptom, while diarrhea is a frequent gastrointestinal issue associated with toxicity.

Side effects of Lithium therapy:

  • Initial Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, and mild diarrhea; minimized by starting with lower doses.
  • Common Effects:
    • Thirst and polyuria (excessive urination) in most patients.
    • Fine tremors may occur even at therapeutic levels.
  • CNS Toxicity (as plasma levels rise): Coarse tremors, dizziness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, hyperreflexia.
  • Overdose (Plasma concentration > 2 mEq/L): Symptoms include muscle twitching, drowsiness, delirium, coma, convulsions, severe vomiting, diarrhea, albuminuria, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Monitoring: Regular monitoring of lithium levels, kidney function, and electrolytes is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not advise for a patient who is already diagnosed with chronic plaque psoriasis and has over 50% of their skin affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral steroids

Explanation:

  • In the case of a patient with chronic plaque psoriasis involving more than 50% of the skin, oral steroids are generally not recommended as a long-term treatment option due to the risk of severe rebound flares and pustular psoriasis upon withdrawal.

Reasons Why Oral Steroids Are Avoided

  1. Rebound Phenomenon
    • Sudden discontinuation can cause severe exacerbation of psoriasis, leading to erythroderma or pustular psoriasis (potentially life-threatening).
  2. Risk of Pustular Psoriasis
    • Systemic steroids can trigger generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP), characterized by widespread sterile pustules, fever, and systemic illness.
  3. Limited Long-Term Efficacy
    • While steroids provide short-term relief, they do not alter disease progression and often require higher doses over time, leading to dependency.

Preferred Long-Term Treatment Options

  • Biologics (e.g., IL-17, IL-23, TNF inhibitors)
  • Methotrexate, cyclosporine, or apremilast (for systemic therapy) (Option A and C)
  • Phototherapy (NB-UVB- Narrowband ultraviolet B) (Option B)
  • Topical therapies (vitamin D analogs, corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors) for localized disease

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a second-line medication for treating tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ethionamide

  • Ethionamide is a second-line anti-tubercular drug, typically used when first-line medications like isoniazid and rifampicin are ineffective or when the tuberculosis infection is resistant to these drugs.
  • It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acids, thereby suppressing bacterial growth and replication.

First-line ATT drugs:

  • Isoniazid
  • Rifampicin
  • Pyrazinamide
  • Ethambutol

Second-line ATT drugs

Group A

Group B

Group C
  • Bedaquilin
  • Levofloxacin or Moxifloxacin
  • Linezolid
  • Cycloserine
  • Clofazimine
  • Delamanid
  • Amikacin
  • Meropenem or Imipenem-cilastatin
  • PAS
  • Ethionamide
  • Ethambutol
  • Pyrazinamide

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Schizoid personality disorder

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of social isolation, emotional coldness, and preference for living alone align with the features of schizoid personality disorder.
  • Schizoid personality disorder is characterised by a persistent pattern of social withdrawal, emotional detachment, and a lack of interest in forming close relationships. Individuals with this condition often prefer solitude and exhibit emotional coldness.
  • The absence of hallucinations or delusions helps differentiate it from psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
     

Schizoid Personality Disorder

Features
  • Lifelong social withdrawal
  • Eccentric, isolated, and lonely
  • Introverted with a bland affect

Diagnosis
  • No psychotic symptoms (vs. schizophrenia, delusional disorder)
  • More withdrawn and aloof (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • No dysphoric loneliness
  • Fewer past relationships, possible autistic reverie
  • No desire for social interaction (vs. avoidant personality disorder)

Treatment
  • Psychotherapy: Build trust, encourage expression
  • Group therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence, medications for specific symptoms (e.g., emotional detachment)

Incorrect Options:

Paranoid personality disorder (Option A) involves pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others, hostility, irritability, anger, difficulty with trust and intimacy, and a cynical view of the world, which is not the case here.

Antisocial personality disorder (Option C) is defined as disregard for the rights of others since age 15, which includes disregard of legal and social rules, history of lying, manipulation, lack of remorse, criminality, impulsivity, irritable/ aggressive, charming demeanour and h/o substance use. This does not align with the patient's social isolation and emotional coldness given in the question.

Emotionally unstable personality disorder (Option D), also called Borderline personality disorder, presents with Tumultuous relationships, identity diffusion, mood swings, impulsivity, fear of abandonment, Feeling empty inside and h/o suicidal attempts, which is more common in females, none of which are present here.

questions.text: In a patient with severe COVID-19, which of the following options is unlikely to provide significant assistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Favipiravir

  • Favipiravir (inhibits RNA polymerase) was initially approved for mild to moderate COVID-19 & not severe cases. However, the current protocol does not recommend the usage of Favipiravir.

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (Option A): Severe COVID-19 is often associated with an increased risk of blood clots and thromboembolic complications. LMWH is commonly used as both a prophylactic and therapeutic anticoagulant in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 to prevent or treat these issues.

Oxygen (Option B): Severe COVID-19 can lead to respiratory distress and hypoxemia (low oxygen levels). Supplemental oxygen therapy is essential in managing these cases, helping to maintain adequate oxygen levels and alleviate respiratory difficulties.

Steroids (Option D), such as dexamethasone, have been shown to reduce mortality and improve outcomes in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19. These drugs have anti-inflammatory effects and help suppress the exaggerated immune response (cytokine storm), which can contribute to severe lung damage.

questions.text: In the physiology viva, the examiner inquires about the individual who initially recorded the first EEG. You respond by admitting that you are unaware of the answer. Sympathetic to your lack of knowledge, the examiner provides a hint indicating that the name resembles a common item found at McDonald's. With this clue, you are able to recall the name and provide the correct response. Which form of memory is involved in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Priming

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the examiner's hint helps you recall the name of the individual who recorded the first EEG. This is an example of priming, which involves the exposure to a clue or stimulus that indirectly influences your ability to retrieve information from memory.
  • It helps with faster recognition or processing of similar stimuli without conscious awareness.

Incorrect Options:

Semantic memory (Option A) is a type of explicit memory that involves storing and recalling factual information and general knowledge, such as knowing the capital of a country or understanding historical events. While you are recalling factual information about the first EEG, the specific retrieval mechanism, in this case, is priming, not semantic memory.

Implicit memory (Option B), non-declarative memory, involves unconscious processes that influence thoughts and behaviours. Priming is a type of Implicit memory, including procedural Memory and associative and non-associative learning. However, this is not the correct answer, as Priming explains the situation more specifically.

Associative learning (Option C) involves learning through association, typically in the context of classical or operant conditioning and doesn’t exactly fit this context as you're recalling a specific fact rather than learning through associations.

questions.text: The normality of 2M HCl when compared to 1M H₂SO₄ is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Same

Normality (N) depends on the number of equivalents of reactive species in a solution.

  • Hydrochloric acid (HCl) dissociates to produce 1 mole of H⁺ per mole of HCl, giving it a normality equal to its molarity.
  • Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) dissociates to produce 2 moles of H⁺ per mole of H₂SO₄, so its normality is double its molarity.

However, in the case of the comparison between 2M HCl and 1M H₂SO₄, we need to consider the equivalents.

  • 2M HCl: Normality = 2M × 1 = 2 N
  • 1M H₂SO₄: Normality = 1M × 2 = 2 N

Thus, the normality of 2M HCl is the same as that of 1M H₂SO₄, both being 2N.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects would most likely be caused by a drug that specifically decreases the reabsorption of serotonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sexual dysfunction

Explanation:

  • Sexual dysfunction is a common side effect of Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), they work by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin in the brain, thus increasing its availability at the synaptic cleft. This enhances serotonin signalling, which is thought to alleviate symptoms of depression and anxiety.
  • Symptoms of sexual dysfunction include:
    • Decreased libido (sexual desire)
    • Erectile dysfunction
    • Delayed ejaculation - therefore, these can be used for the treatment of premature ejaculation.
    • Anorgasmia (inability to achieve orgasm)
  • Other Side effects of SSRIs include:
    • Nausea, vomiting (Most common)
    • Diarrhoea (Option A ruled out)
    • Insomnia
    • Anxiety during the initial weeks of treatment
    • Sexual dysfunction
    • Increased risk of suicide soon after starting drug
    • Bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
    • Loss of weight (Option D ruled out)


Sialorrhea (Option C) is defined as excessive salivation, and it is not generally associated with SSRIs.

questions.text: What is the probable cause for the development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received intravenous morphine for pain relief after a road traffic accident, considering the presence of pelvic fracture and head trauma?

choices.text: CO₂ retention due to opioid use

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - CO₂ retention due to opioid use

  • Opioids like morphine depress the respiratory system by acting on the brainstem's respiratory centers, reducing the respiratory drive and sensitivity to CO₂ levels. In this case, morphine likely caused respiratory depression, leading to hypoventilation and CO₂ retention, contributing to the patient's respiratory difficulty.

Head injury is contraindicated in morphine usage:

  • Morphine retains CO2, increasing ICP which adds to already increased ICP
  • Therapeutic doses can result in marked respiratory depression
  • Interferes with the assessment of progress by causing miosis, vomiting & altered mentation

Pelvic Fracture (Option A): While a pelvic fracture can cause significant pain and may lead to complications like internal bleeding or organ injury, it is unlikely to cause respiratory difficulty in this case directly. The onset of respiratory difficulty shortly after the administration of IV morphine points more toward a drug-related cause.

Cerebral Edema (Option C), which occurs due to brain swelling from trauma, is unlikely to be the cause of respiratory difficulty following IV morphine administration. It typically presents with other neurological signs, such as altered consciousness or increased intracranial pressure, rather than respiratory symptoms alone.

Pulmonary Embolism (Option D): While pulmonary embolism can cause sudden respiratory distress, it is less probable here, given that the respiratory difficulty occurred soon after IV morphine administration. The timing and known opioid side effects make CO₂ retention due to opioid use a more likely explanation.

questions.text: Which one of the options below is not classified as a form of subcortical dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pick’s disease

Explanation:

  • Pick’s disease is a form of frontotemporal dementia that involves the progressive degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain.
  • It is characterised by early personality and behavioural changes, including disinhibition, lack of empathy, and hyperorality, while other cognitive functions remain intact initially.

Frontotemporal Dementia (Pick Disease)

  • Affects frontotemporal regions with atrophy.
  • It involves neuronal loss, gliosis, and Pick bodies, which are hallmark features of this condition.
  • Accounts for about 5% of irreversible dementias.
  • More common in men, especially with a family history.
  • Early symptoms include personality and behavioural changes; other cognitive functions are preserved.
  • Typically, it begins before age 75; familial cases may start earlier.
  • Features like hypersexuality and hyperorality are more common than in Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Difficult to distinguish from Alzheimer’s in early stages.

Incorrect Options:

Parkinson’s disease (Option B) is a neurodegenerative disorder that can lead to subcortical dementia. The underlying neurodegeneration is in the basal ganglia, which is part of the subcortical structures. It can progress to dementia, especially when cognitive symptoms appear later in the disease course.

Huntington’s disease (Option C) is another condition that causes subcortical dementia. It is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the basal ganglia and leads to cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms, and motor abnormalities.


Wilson’s disease (Option D) is a metabolic disorder that results in abnormal copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other organs. It can lead to subcortical dementia due to its effects on the basal ganglia, and it may also cause neurological and psychiatric symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the below statements is accurate regarding disulfiram?

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients feel drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated persons
Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - When used with alcohol, the patients feel drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression

  • Disulfiram works by inhibiting the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for alcohol metabolism.
  • When alcohol is consumed while on disulfiram therapy, there is an accumulation of acetaldehyde, a toxic metabolite, leading to unpleasant symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and headache.
  • It may last for 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.

It is an anti-craving drug (Option B): Disulfiram is not considered an anti-craving drug. It works by causing an aversive reaction to alcohol, discouraging drinking, rather than directly addressing alcohol cravings or the psychological aspects of dependence.

It can be initiated even in minimally motivated persons (Option C): Disulfiram is typically initiated in individuals who are highly motivated to quit drinking, as they need to understand the risks of alcohol consumption while on the medication. It is not suitable for minimally motivated individuals.

Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug (Option D): The effects of disulfiram can last 7-14 days after discontinuation. Patients should be counseled about this extended effect to prevent disulfiram-alcohol reactions.

questions.text: What should be the treatment approach for a 7-year-old child who has been experiencing bed-wetting about twice a week for the past year, following a thorough investigation to exclude any underlying organic cause?

choices.text: Bladder training, with the reward for delaying micturition during daytime

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bell and pad-based classification conditioning

Explanation:

  • Bed-wetting, also known as nocturnal enuresis, is a common problem in children, often occurring during sleep. T
  • The bell and pad method is the most appropriate first-line treatment for bed-wetting in children without organic causes.
  • This method involves a moisture-sensitive pad attached to the child's underwear.
  • When the child begins to wet the bed, the bell rings, waking them up and helping them associate the sensation of a full bladder with the action of waking up.
  • Over time, this conditioning process helps the child learn to wake up before urinating, effectively reducing bed-wetting.

Management of enuresis

Behavioural modifications:

  • Reassurance.
  • Encourage voiding before bed.
  • Restrict evening fluid intake (40% in the morning, 40% at noon, 20% after 6 PM).
  • Avoid caffeinated drinks.
  • Motivational Therapy: Use verbal praise and rewards for dry nights.
  • Bell and pad method (Alarm Therapy).

Medications:

  • Short-Term: Oral desmopressin for immediate relief.
  • Long-Term: Oxybutynin or tolterodine to reduce bladder contractions. Imipramine is avoided due to side effects (Option A ruled out)


Psychodynamic psychotherapy (Option B) focuses on resolving unconscious conflicts but is not a first-line treatment for bed-wetting. This approach is not typically indicated for primary nocturnal enuresis, especially when there are no significant emotional or psychological factors contributing to the issue.

Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime (Option C): While bladder training can be effective in treating daytime urinary issues, it is generally not as effective for nocturnal enuresis. It might improve bladder control but does not specifically address bed-wetting at night.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with a fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later, he presented with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Amoxicillin

  • Amoxicillin is a frequently prescribed antibiotic, and one of its known side effects is the development of a maculopapular rash, which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction and is a common sign of an allergic response to amoxicillin.
  • It usually appears a few days after starting the medication, presenting as small, flat, reddened lesions that may be raised or papular.

Aminopenicillin: Amoxicillin and Ampicillin are amino penicillins. Incidence of rashes is about 9%.

  • Better oral absorption with lesser incidence of diarrhea
  • More active against penicillin-resistant pneumococci

Prednisolone (Option A) is a corticosteroid used to treat asthma and other inflammatory conditions. While corticosteroids can cause side effects such as skin thinning and increased susceptibility to skin infections, a maculopapular rash is not a typical adverse reaction to prednisolone.

Salbutamol (Option B) is a bronchodilator used to manage asthma symptoms by relaxing airway muscles and improving airflow. It is not associated with causing a maculopapular rash as a side effect.

Fexofenadine (Option D) is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, itching, and runny nose. It is generally well-tolerated and does not typically cause a maculopapular rash as a side effect.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A

Explanation:

The optic nerve, also known as cranial nerve II, is primarily responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is involved in vision and does not directly control the movement of the eyeball.

 

 

Oculomotor nerve (Option B): Cranial nerve III, or the oculomotor nerve, innervates key extraocular muscles, dictating eye movements. It governs the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.

Abducens nerve (Option C): The abducens nerve, or cranial nerve VI, controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. It is responsible for the abduction (outward movement) of the eye.
Trochlear nerve (Option D): The trochlear nerve, or cranial nerve IV, innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye. It plays a role in the downward and inward movement of the eye.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old child experiencing selective mutism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Childhood anxiety disorder

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis for a child who exhibits selective mutism is a childhood anxiety disorder.
  • It is characterised by consistently failing to speak in certain social situations (like in schools) despite being able to speak in other situations (like at home).
  • Age of onset: 4 - 8 years
  • Treatment: A comprehensive approach involving psychoeducation for the family, CBT, and SSRIs as required.
  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is the first line of management in school-going children.

Incorrect Options:

Childhood depression (Option A) usually involves pervasive sadness, loss of interest, fatigue, and irritability, but mutism is not a characteristic of depression alone.

Childhood psychosis (Option B) refers to conditions where a child loses touch with reality, often presenting with hallucinations and delusions. Children with selective mutism are typically not psychotic; they can perceive reality and understand social norms but simply experience extreme anxiety in specific situations, preventing them from speaking.


Hyperkinetic disorder (Option D) is also called as ADHD, and it involves symptoms like inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity, which lead to difficulty maintaining focus and control over behaviour, particularly in settings like school. Children with ADHD generally do not refuse to speak in specific settings. Instead, their struggles are related to attention and activity regulation.

questions.text: Which statement is accurate regarding a patient receiving a high dosage of both penicillin and gentamicin?

choices.text: TDM is done for penicillin because of the narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - TDM is done for gentamicin

  • Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is especially important for gentamicin, an aminoglycoside, because it has a narrow therapeutic index and can cause toxic effects like nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.
  • Monitoring blood levels ensures the drug remains within a safe and effective range.
  • Penicillin generally does not require TDM as it has a wider therapeutic index. However, in some cases of high-dose therapy or renal impairment, monitoring may be necessary to avoid toxicity.

Drugs that require Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM):

  • Drugs with erratic pharmacokinetics and low safety margins, such as digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycoside antibiotics, lithium, and tricyclic antidepressants.
  • Drugs with high individual variability, including antidepressants and lithium.
  • Toxic drugs in renal failure, such as aminoglycosides and vancomycin.
  • Cases of poisoning, where TDM is essential to assess and manage drug levels.
  • Unexplained therapeutic failure, such as with antimicrobials.
  • Patient compliance monitoring, particularly with psychotropic drugs.

Drugs Not Requiring Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM):

  • Drugs with easily measurable responses, including antihypertensives, hypoglycemics, diuretics, oral anticoagulants, and inhalational general anesthetics.
  • Drugs activated in the body, such as levodopa.
  • 'Hit and run' drugs with prolonged effects, including MAO inhibitors, reserpine, guanethidine, and omeprazole.
  • Drugs with irreversible actions, such as organophosphates and phenoxybenzamine.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fibrous joint

Explanation:

  • The middle radioulnar joint, located between the radius and ulna bones in the forearm, facilitates forearm rotation for pronation and supination. It's a fibrous joint known as a syndesmosis, characterized by dense connective tissue like ligaments or interosseous membranes holding the bones together.

Fibrous joints connect bones with fibrous connective tissue, allowing minimal movement. They come in three main types:

Sutures

Gomphosis

Syndesmosis
  • Joints between two skull bones.
  • Sutures are immobile in adults and slightly mobile in babies.
  • Gomphosis is an immobile joint.
  • Tooth-socket joints.

 

 
  • Slightly mobile joint.
  • Examples include the radioulnar joint and inferior tibiofibular joint.

 

Plane synovial (Option A): Plane synovial joints, also known as gliding joints, are characterized by flat articular surfaces that allow sliding or gliding movements between bones.

Primary cartilaginous (Option B): Primary cartilaginous joints, also known as synchondroses, are joints where the bones are connected by hyaline cartilage.

Secondary cartilaginous (Option C): Secondary cartilaginous joints, also known as symphyses, are joints where the bones are connected by fibrocartilage.

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T3-T4

Explanation:

  • The image shows the arch of the aorta, brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery, we can make an inference about the level of the cross-section.
  • The cross-section shown in the image corresponds to the level between the T3 and T4 vertebrae.

At this level, the aortic arch is usually seen, and the trachea begins to bifurcate into the right and left main bronchi.

  • Level of the Thoracic Inlet: This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter.
  • Level of the Aortic Arch: Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus.
  • Level of the Carina: At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  • Level of the Heart: The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9. You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries).
  • Level of the Diaphragm: The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures.
  • Level of the Esophagus: The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10.
  • Level of the Thoracic Spine: The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae.

 

Fig: Showing CT view of axial section of the thorax

 

T1-T2 (Option A): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T1 and T2 vertebrae, which is different from the structures mentioned in the image description.

T2-T3 (Option B): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T2 and T3 vertebrae, which is also different from the structures mentioned in the image description.

T4-T5 (Option D): This option indicates a cross-section at the level between the T4 and T5 vertebrae, which is not consistent with the structures seen in the image.

questions.text: What are the distinguishing characteristics between delirium and dementia in Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

Explanation:

  • Delirium is characterised by a sudden and acute onset, often occurring over a short period of hours to days.
  • The definition of delirium is an acute decline in both the level of consciousness and cognition with particular impairment in attention.
  • This is not the case with dementia, which develops gradually over months to years.

Distinguishing characteristics of Delirium and Dementia

Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

(Option C ruled out)

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, it may occur in advanced stages

(Option C ruled out)

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages


Acuity of onset and agitation (Option A): While agitation can occur in delirium and dementia, the key distinguishing feature is the onset. Delirium involves a rapid onset of agitation, confusion, and fluctuating attention, whereas agitation in dementia is usually seen in later stages.

Agitation and irritation (Option D) are also present in delirium and dementia; hence, they are not the primary distinguishing features.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main concern when considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Suicidal risk:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) have been associated with an increased risk of suicide, particularly in the early stages of treatment or during the discontinuation phase. This risk is a significant concern when considering the discharge of a patient, as they may have greater access to the medication and could be at higher risk for self-harm.

Mechanism of Action (MOA) of Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs): Inhibition of Reuptake: TCAs primarily work by inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters, serotonin and norepinephrine, into presynaptic nerve terminals. This increases the concentration of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their effects.

Antagonism of Receptors: In addition to blocking reuptake, TCAs also interact with various receptors, contributing to their side effects:

  • Histamine receptors: Cause sedation and weight gain.
  • Alpha-adrenergic receptors: Lead to orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia.
  • Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors: Cause anticholinergic side effects, such as dry mouth and constipation.
  • 5HT receptors: weight gain d/t increased appetite

Need for drug monitoring (Option A): Although some medications, including TCAs, may require monitoring in certain situations, routine drug monitoring is not the primary concern for discharge. TDM is typically used for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index or significant drug interactions, which is not the case for TCAs.

ECG monitoring for arrhythmias (Option B): While TCAs can cause cardiac issues like QT prolongation, routine ECG monitoring is not the main focus during discharge. Any necessary ECG assessments would have been addressed earlier in the hospital stay.

Sedation being the side effect (Option D): While sedation is a known side effect of TCAs and should be monitored, the primary concern during discharge is not sedation. More critical factors, such as suicide risk, need to be considered when planning discharge.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures?

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - B and C only

Valproate and Ethosuximide are commonly used to treat absence seizures.

Absence seizures: Absence seizures, also called petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure that involves a brief loss of consciousness or awareness. These seizures usually last only a few seconds and are marked by a sudden interruption of activity, blank staring, and subtle motor movements like blinking or lip-smacking.

  • Ethosuximide (C) is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures. It blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • Valproate (B) is the DOC in atypical absence seizures.
  • Phenytoin and Carbamazepine (A) are contraindicated in the absence seizures.

Gabapentin (D) is an antiepileptic drug that is primarily used to treat focal seizures and neuropathic pain. While it may have some efficacy in certain types of generalized seizures, it is not typically considered a first-line treatment for absence seizures.

questions.text:
Which of the subsequent options aids in distinguishing a fixed dilated pupil?


	Phenylephrine
	1% Pilocarpine
	0.1% Pilocarpine
	Cocaine 0.5%
	Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 3

Explanation:

  • To differentiate a fixed dilated pupil, the use of specific pharmacological agents can be helpful.
  • Pilocarpine is a parasympathomimetic drug that stimulates the pupillary sphincter muscle, causing miosis (constriction of the pupil). If the dilated pupil responds to pilocarpine and constricts, it indicates that the dilated pupil is likely due to parasympathetic denervation or dysfunction. Normal pupil react to 1% pilocarpine below this concentration, normal pupil don't react.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action for a 30 year old woman who has been diagnosed with carcinoma in situ of the cervix and has no apparent visible growth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Colposcopy and biopsy

Explanation:

  • Carcinoma in situ refers to the presence of abnormal cells that have not invaded beyond the surface layer of the cervix. In this scenario, the next step in management would be to perform a colposcopy, which allows for a detailed examination of the cervix using a special magnifying instrument. During colposcopy, targeted biopsies can be taken to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the abnormality.


Hysterectomy (Option A), the surgical removal of the uterus, is not the initial management for carcinoma in situ. It may be considered in more advanced stages or if other treatments have failed.

Conization (Option B), also known as a cone biopsy, involves removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. While it may be performed in certain cases where the lesion is visible, colposcopy and biopsy are usually the initial steps to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the abnormality. Conization also leads to a short cervix which causes cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions. It may cause stenosis of cervix which may lead to infertility

Given the diagnosis of carcinoma in situ, a more immediate evaluation and intervention are necessary, rather than waiting for a follow-up after 6 months (Option D).

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with chronic back pain and neck stiffness. An X-ray cervical spine is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH)

Explanation:

  • Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) is a condition characterized by calcification and ossification of ligaments, particularly the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine.
  • On X-ray, it presents as flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebrae without significant disc space narrowing or sacroiliac joint involvement.

Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH)

Feature

Description

Etiology

Unknown; associated with metabolic conditions (e.g., diabetes)

Radiological Features

Continuous flowing ossifications over vertebral bodies, preservation of disc spaces

Common Location

Cervical and thoracic spine

Symptoms

Stiffness, chronic pain, dysphagia if cervical involvement

Differential Diagnosis

Ankylosing spondylitis, degenerative disc disease

Management

Symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs, physical therapy

 

57-year-old male patient diagnosed with both Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis and Spondyloarthritis. Technique: Lateral and Antero-Posterior (AP) X-rays of the thoracic Spine Findings: Flowing ossifications involving the anterior longitudinal ligament along multiple contiguous thoracic levels with preservation of the intervertebral disc height at the involved

A case of diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis involving only cervical spine (C3-6). Flowing bridging ossification and partial ossification (arrows) of three contiguous disc levels (C3-6) are noted in consecutive sagittal images (A, B) of whole spine computed tomography.

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option A): Incorrect because it typically involves sacroiliac joint fusion and syndesmophytes rather than flowing ossifications.

Klippel-Feil syndrome (Option C): Incorrect because it is a congenital disorder with cervical vertebral fusion, not ossification of ligaments.

Sprengel deformity (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with congenital elevation of the scapula, not spinal ligament ossification.

questions.text:
Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each:


	
		
			
			Bacteria
			
			
			Drug of Choice
			
		
		
			
			A. Bacteroides
			
			
			1. Vancomycin
			
		
		
			
			B. MRSA
			
			
			2. Metronidazole
			
		
		
			
			C. Hemophilus
			
			
			3. Meropenem
			
		
		
			
			D. Klebsiella
			
			
			4. Penicillin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

Bacteria

Drug of Choice

Bacteroides

Metronidazole

MRSA

Vancomycin

Hemophilus

Penicillin

Klebsiella

Meropenem

 

  • Bacteroides: The preferred treatment for Bacteroides infections is metronidazole (option 2), which provides excellent coverage against anaerobic bacteria, including Bacteroides species.
  • MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus): Vancomycin is the drug of choice for treating MRSA infections. It is specifically effective against this antibiotic-resistant strain of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Hemophilus: Penicillin is the standard treatment for infections caused by Hemophilus influenzae, a common cause of Hemophilus infections.
  • Klebsiella: Meropenem is the preferred antibiotic for Klebsiella infections, offering broad-spectrum activity against many Gram-negative bacteria, including Klebsiella species.

questions.text:
True statement regarding KF ring:


	Seen in all patient with neurological involvement
	Is pathognomonic for Wilson’s disease
	Resolves with desferroxamine
	Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement
	Seen in superior and inferior descemets membrane
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 5

Explanation:

Statement 1: KF ring is seen on all patients with neurologic symptoms because neurological symptoms are caused due to deposition of copper in basal ganglia, thus can deposit in cornea

Statement 2: KF ring are seen in Wilson disease, primary biliary cholangitis and neonatal cholestasis

Statement 4: KF ring is seen in only 50% patients with hepatic involvement

 

Wilson disease:

Hepatolenticular degeneration

Pathophysiology:

  • Autosomal recessive (positive family history)
  • Mutation in ATP7B gene (copper transporting P-type adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase), present in chromosome 13 (13q14).
  • Decreased biliary copper excretion and diffuse accumulation of copper in the cytosol of hepatocytes.
  • Later, copper is redistributed to other tissues once the liver is saturated with copper.

Clinical features:

  • Liver: Asymptomatic hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly), subacute or chronic hepatitis, acute hepatic failure, and portal hypertension
  • Neurology: Intention tremor, dysarthria, rigid dystonia, Parkinsonism, choreiform movements, lack of motor coordination, deterioration in school performance, psychosis, or behavioral changes
  • Psychiatric manifestations: Depression, personality changes, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behavior, or psychosis
  • Eye: KF (Kayser Fleischer) ring in Descement membrane layer of cornea (Statement 5)
  • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure

Diagnosis:

  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL)
  • Serum-free copper level >1.6 µmol/L
  • Urinary copper excretion (normally <40 µg/day) is increased to >100 µg/day
  • Liver biopsy (Gold standard): Hepatic copper content >250 µg/g dry weight of liver

Treatment:

  • Dietary intake of copper (Avoid liver, shellfish, nuts, and chocolate) should be restricted to <1 mg/day
  • Symptomatic patients: Copper-chelating agents
    • D-penicillamine (Statement 3 ruled out)
    • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride
  • Zinc impairs the gastrointestinal absorption of copper

questions.text:
Iritis is not seen in:


	Rheumatoid arthritis
	SLE
	Bechet’s disease
	Psoriatic arthritis
	Ulcerative colitis
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) 1 and 2

Explanation:

Conditions where iritis is seen:

  • Behcet’s disease (Statement 3 ruled out): Characterized by recurrent uveitis, including iritis, genital involvement and oral involvement.
  • Psoriatic arthritis (Statement 4 ruled out): A seronegative spondyloarthropathy frequently associated with anterior uveitis including iritis, urethritis and arthritis.
  • Ulcerative colitis (Statement 5 ruled out): Iritis is common in inflammatory bowel disease, as it shares a systemic inflammatory pathway.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: Iritis is rarely seen in adult-onset rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is more commonly associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), especially in ANA-positive cases.
  • SLE: Systemic lupus erythematosus typically affects other ocular tissues, such as the retina and optic nerve, rather than causing iritis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true?

A. Morphine is used in pulmonary edema

B. Pethidine is used in biliary colic

C. Indomethacin is used for headache

D. Aspirin is used in peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A, B, and C

A. Morphine used in pulmonary edema: This statement is actually true. Morphine is sometimes used in acute pulmonary edema to relieve anxiety and reduce the sensation of breathlessness. It works by decreasing preload and afterload and providing pain relief. However, it is not the first-line treatment, as diuretics are preferred.

B. Pethidine used in biliary colic: True. Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is commonly used for relieving pain in biliary colic because it does not cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi (as morphine might), and it helps in reducing pain effectively.

C. Indomethacin is used for headaches: True. Indomethacin, an NSAID, is often used to treat certain types of headaches, including cluster headaches.

D. Aspirin used in peptic ulcer disease: This statement is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcers due to its irritating effect on the gastric mucosa and its ability to inhibit prostaglandins that protect the stomach lining.

questions.text:
True regarding POAG:


	Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy
	First degree relatives have more chances of developing steroid induced glaucoma
	Dilatation of pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP
	First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG
	Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio
questions.solution:
Correct option: C) 2 and 5 only

Explanation:

Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG)

Characteristics:

  • Intraocular Pressure: Elevated (>21 mm Hg) on multiple occasions.
  • Anterior Chamber Angle: Open and normal in appearance (Statement 3).
  • Optic Disc: Characteristic cupping , normal C:D ratio in early stages (Statement 5).
  • Visual Field: Specific defects present.

Risk Factors:

  • Elevated IOP: Asymmetry of IOP of ≥4 mmHg is considered significant. (Option A)
  • Family History: Higher risk in siblings (10%) (Statement 4) and offspring (4%). Involves polygenic inheritance with genes like MYOC, OPTN, and WDR36. (Option C)
  • Age: Increased risk with age, especially between the 5th and 7th decades of life.
  • Race: Higher prevalence and severity in Black individuals compared to Whites.
  • Myopia: Increased risk in myopic individuals. (Option D)
  • Thinner Central Corneal Thickness (CCT) (<555 µm) is an independent risk factor.
  • Cigarette Smoking: Increased risk
  • Blood Pressure: Higher prevalence in hypertensives; diastolic perfusion pressure <55 mm Hg is a significant risk factor. (Option B)
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Increased in Graves' ophthalmic disease.
  • Corticosteroid Responsiveness: Greater risk of IOP rise with topical steroid therapy (Statement 2).

Pathogenesis:

  • The rise in IOP in POAG occurs due to decreased aqueous outflow facility. This is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening and apposition of Schlemm's canal wall.
  • Contributing factors include thickening and sclerosis of the trabecular meshwork, narrowing of intertrabecular spaces, deposition of amorphous material in the juxtacanalicular space, and collapse of Schlemm's canal.

Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy (Statement 1) although trabecular meshwork is seen in gonioscopy, abnormalities in the trabecular meshwork cannot be observed during gonioscopy.

questions.text: What is the subsequent course of action in the management of a 50-year-old female patient experiencing abnormal uterine bleeding for a duration of two months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endometrial sampling

Explanation:

  • In a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, the next step in management is to perform endometrial sampling. Abnormal uterine bleeding in postmenopausal women can be a sign of endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer. Endometrial sampling, such as endometrial biopsy or hysteroscopy with biopsy, is essential for obtaining tissue for histological examination to rule out any underlying malignancy or precancerous conditions.


A levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine contraceptive device (LNG-IUCD) (Option A) is not the next line of management for abnormal uterine bleeding in a postmenopausal woman. It may be considered for managing abnormal uterine bleeding in premenopausal women.

Progestin-only pills (POP) (Option B) are not the first-line management for abnormal uterine bleeding in a postmenopausal woman. POPs are primarily used for contraception in premenopausal women.

Hysterectomy (Option C) is not the initial step in the management of abnormal uterine bleeding. It is typically reserved for cases where medical management or less invasive interventions have failed or when there is a definite diagnosis of malignancy.

questions.text: The physician suggests a Pap smear for a 45 year old patient who has been experiencing recurrent trichomonas vaginitis infections. The patient inquires about the reason for this test. How would you appropriately explain the purpose of the Pap smear?

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a screening test for cervical cancer

Explanation:

  • A Pap smear is primarily a screening test for cervical cancer.
  • It is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix that could potentially develop into cervical cancer if left untreated (Options B, C, and D).
  • The procedure involves collecting cells from the cervix and examining them under a microscope to identify precancerous or cancerous changes.
  • Regular Pap smears are an important part of cervical cancer prevention and early detection.

questions.text: Which of the options below represents a characteristic observed in cases of large bowel obstruction?

choices.text: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dilated loops with haustrations

Explanation:

  • Large bowel obstruction (LBO) typically presents with dilated loops of the colon showing prominent haustra, which are incomplete and widely spaced folds.
  • Unlike small bowel obstruction (SBO), haustral markings do not extend across the entire lumen.

Radiological Features of Bowel Obstruction

Feature

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

Large Bowel Obstruction (LBO)

Dilated loops

Central, thin-walled

Peripheral, thick-walled

Folds

Plica circulares (valvulae conniventes)

Haustrations (do not extend completely across the lumen)

"String of pearls" sign

Yes (air-fluid levels in SBO)

String of pearl appearance

 

No

Transition point

Small bowel

Colon or rectosigmoid region

Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circularis (Option A): Incorrect because plicae circulares are characteristic of small bowel obstruction (SBO), not LBO.

String of pearls sign (Option C): Incorrect because this is seen in small bowel obstruction, representing multiple small gas bubbles trapped in fluid-filled loops.

Central dilated bowel loops (Option D): Incorrect because small bowel obstructions usually present with centrally dilated loops, whereas large bowel obstructions show peripheral dilation.

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain and moderate PV bleeding. She was hemodynamically stable. On USG, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal, and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management?

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follow-up with beta- HCG

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the absence of a gestational sac in the uterus, along with vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal pai,n raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy. The next step would be to follow up with beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG) levels to monitor the trend. Serial measurements of beta-HCG can help determine whether the pregnancy is viable or if it is likely an ectopic pregnancy.

 

A complete abortion (Option A) refers to the passage of all products of conception. However, in this case, the absence of a gestational sac and the symptoms of pain and bleeding suggest the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy, which requires further evaluation.

Given the suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy, admission and observation (Option B) may not be sufficient as it could lead to a delay in appropriate management.

Diagnostic laparoscopy (Option C) may be considered if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of hemoperitoneum or signs of rupture. However, it is not the initial step in the management of suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a pregnant woman with high blood pressure, experiencing stomach pain, vaginal bleeding, and absence of fetal movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements is suggestive of abruptio placenta.
  • Abruptio placenta refers to the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It is a serious obstetric emergency that requires immediate evaluation and management.

 

Placenta previa (Option B) is a condition where the placenta implants low in the uterus, partially or completely covering the cervix. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding, not associated with abdominal pain or loss of fetal movements.

Hydramnios, or polyhydramnios (Option C), refers to an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid. It may cause abdominal discomfort, but it does not typically present with bleeding or loss of fetal movements.

Preterm labor (Option D) refers to the onset of regular uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. It may present with abdominal pain and contractions but is not associated with bleeding or loss of fetal movements.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male arrived at the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3, indicating a level of consciousness. No fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull were detected. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and showed no abnormalities. The probable diagnosis is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

Explanation:

  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of E2M2V3 (Total: 7) suggests a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).

  • History of a car accident suggests high-velocity trauma, which is a common cause of DAI.

  • Normal CT scan does not rule out DAI, as it often presents with microscopic damage to axons, which may not be visible on a non-contrast CT but can be detected using MRI (susceptibility-weighted imaging or DWI).

  • Absence of hydrocephalus, fractures, or increased intracranial pressure further supports DAI, as other traumatic brain injuries (like hemorrhages or herniation) would likely show visible abnormalities on CT.

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

 

Feature

Description

Etiology

High-speed trauma, rotational forces, falls

Mechanism

Shearing of axons due to rapid acceleration/deceleration

Clinical Features

Unconsciousness, low GCS, no focal deficits

Imaging Findings

Normal CT initially; MRI shows microhemorrhages (FLAIR, GRE sequences)

Management

Supportive care, ICU monitoring, neuroprotection

 

 

Post-concussion syndrome (Option B): Incorrect because post-concussion syndrome usually follows mild TBI, with symptoms like headache, dizziness, and mood changes, but does not cause low GCS.

Extradural hemorrhage (Option C): Incorrect because extradural (epidural) hemorrhage appears as a biconvex hyperdense lesion on CT, often with a lucid interval, which is absent here.

Herniation of brain (Option D): Incorrect because brain herniation would show CT signs like midline shift, compressed ventricles, and brainstem displacement, none of which are seen in this case.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in the management of a 45-year-old female patient who has been diagnosed with a 14-week-sized fibroid but does not exhibit any specific symptoms?

choices.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hysterectomy

Explanation:

  • Hysterectomy is not indicated in an asymptomatic patient with a fibroid unless there are other compelling reasons for the procedure. As mentioned in the question, the size of the fibroid is that of a 14-week fetus, which would be >10cm.
  • It can cause compression of the bowel and bladder, torsion, degeneration, or it can detach. As the patient has completed the family and does not have any specific symptoms, hysterectomy would be the best option.

 

Myomectomy (Option B), which involves surgical removal of fibroids, is generally performed when symptomatic fibroids are causing significant issues or fertility problems. It is not necessary for an asymptomatic patient with a complete family.
In an asymptomatic patient with a fibroid of <5cm (Option C), the next step in management is typically observation without intervention. Asymptomatic fibroids do not require immediate treatment, especially in the absence of symptoms such as pain, abnormal bleeding, or pressure symptoms.

Medical management (Option D) is used to control symptoms or shrink fibroids temporarily. As the patient is asymptomatic, medical management is not necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the rise in ESR during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fibrinogen

Explanation:

Fibrinogen is an acute-phase reactant, which means its levels increase in response to inflammation. During pregnancy, hormonal changes lead to increased levels of fibrinogen, resulting in an elevated ESR. This increase in fibrinogen is a normal physiological response and helps prepare the body for potential bleeding during childbirth.

  • During pregnancy, an increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a common finding.
  • ESR is a non-specific indicator of inflammation and reflects the rate at which red blood cells settle in a vertical tube over a specific time period.
  • It is influenced by several factors, including changes in blood composition and hormonal fluctuations during pregnancy.

 

While albumin (Option A) is an important plasma protein involved in maintaining oncotic pressure and transporting various substances, changes in its levels during pregnancy don't have a major impact on ESR.

Platelets (Option B) are essential for blood clotting, but they do not significantly affect ESR. Their count may change during pregnancy, but they don't cause a rise in ESR.

Anti-thrombin antibodies (Option D) affect the anticoagulant function of anti-thrombin III but are not associated with increased ESR during pregnancy. The rise in ESR is primarily linked to increased acute-phase proteins like fibrinogen.

questions.text: Which of the following is excluded from the composition of the fetal biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contraction stress test

Explanation:

  • Contraction stress test is not a part of the fetal biophysical profile.
  • The contraction stress test assesses the response of the fetal heart rate to contractions induced by administering oxytocin or nipple stimulation. It is used to evaluate the fetal response to stress and to assess placental function.

 

Fetal movement (Option A) assesses the presence and quantity of fetal movements. It involves observing the fetus's body or limb movements within a specific time period.

Fetal breathing (Option B) evaluates the presence of rhythmic fetal breathing movements. It assesses the movement of the fetal diaphragm and helps determine fetal lung maturity.

The Non-Stress Test (NST) (Option C) measures the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movement. It assesses the reactivity and accelerations in the fetal heart rate, which indicates a healthy and responsive fetus.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a young girl who experiences constant urine dribbling, despite voiding normally, and has never been completely dry since birth, according to her parents?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ectopic ureter

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of an ectopic ureter. This is a condition where the ureter, instead of terminating into the urinary bladder, terminates at a different site.

Ectopic ureter

Etiology
  • Results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication.

Pathology
  • Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, commonly associated with duplication of the ureter.

Pathophysiology
  • Females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence.
  • Males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence.

Types
  • Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases).
  • Unilateral ectopic ureters.

Clinical Features
  • Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding.
  • Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter.

Diagnosis
  • Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU).
  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU).

Laboratory Investigations
  • Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU).

Complications
  • Persistent incontinence in females.
  • Potential recurrent urinary tract infections.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Urethral Stricture : Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence.
  • Neurogenic Bladder :

Treatment
  • Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence.

Ureterocele (Option B) is a condition where the lower end of the ureter balloons out and forms a cyst-like structure within the bladder. This can cause urinary obstruction and lead to symptoms such as urinary frequency, urgency, or recurrent urinary tract infections.

Congenital megaureter (Option C) refers to the dilation or enlargement of the ureter. It can be caused by an obstruction or a functional abnormality of the ureter. Congenital megaureter can cause urinary stasis, infections, or vesicoureteric reflux, but does not cause continuous urine leakage.

Vesicoureteric reflux (Option D) is a condition where urine flows backwards from the bladder up into the ureters. It presents with recurrent UTIs and possible hydronephrosis but does not cause continuous dribbling.

questions.text: At what point of cervical dilatation should a nursing assistant in the obstetric care unit begin plotting a paragraph to track labor progress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4cm

Explanation:

  • A partograph is a graphical tool used to monitor the progress of labor. It helps healthcare providers track cervical dilatation, the descent of the presenting part, and other vital parameters during labor. The graph is divided into different sections, and plotting begins at a specific point in cervical dilatation.
  • According to the standard practice, plotting on the partograph should start when the cervix is dilated at 4cm. This is considered the active phase of labor when regular contractions and progressive cervical dilation are expected. Starting the plot at 4cm allows for the assessment of the labor progress and helps identify any deviations or abnormalities that may require intervention.

 

2 cm dilation (Option A) indicates the early phase of labor, not yet active, where contractions are irregular, making it unsuitable for accurate monitoring of active labor.

Delaying plotting until 7 cm dilation (Option C) may result in missed opportunities for early detection of labor abnormalities.

While 6 cm dilatation (Option D) is within the active phase of labor, it is recommended to begin at 4 cm for more comprehensive monitoring of labor progress.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Right occipito-anterior

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the right occipito-anterior position, which means that the baby’s occiput is positioned toward the right side of the mother’s pelvis and is facing the front (anterior) of the pelvis.
  • The term "position" refers to the orientation of a specific part of the fetus in relation to the maternal birth canal, either to the right or left side.
  • The fetal landmarks used for identification in various presentations are the occiput (for occipital presentation), chin (for face presentation), and sacrum (for breech presentation).
  • Depending on which side of the mother’s pelvis the presenting part is located, the positions are designated as left or right occipital (LO and RO), left or right mental (LM and RM), and left or right sacral (LS and RS).
  • Additionally, the position of the defined landmark is described in relation to the anterior (A), transverse (T), or posterior (P) parts of the maternal pelvis.

 

In right occipito-posterior (Option A), the baby's occiput is toward the right side of the mother's pelvis but facing the back (posterior) of the pelvis. In this scenario, the baby's back would be positioned more towards the mother's back.

The left occipito-anterior position (Option B) describes the occiput of the baby being toward the left side of the mother's pelvis and facing the front (anterior) of the pelvis.

The left occipito-posterior position (Option C) indicates that the baby's occiput is positioned toward the left side of the mother's pelvis but facing the back (posterior) of the pelvis. In this case, the baby's back would be positioned more towards the mother's back.

questions.text: Which of the following should be administered in addition to airway management for a 3-year-old child experiencing symptoms such as rapid breathing, high fever, noisy breathing during inhalation, and difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production within 4-6 hours of the onset of fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IV ceftriaxone

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epiglottitis. The primary treatment for acute epiglottitis is the prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

Acute Epiglottitis

Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest.

 

Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)

  • Post-vaccine Era:

    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus

    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination.

Clinical Features

  • Child appears toxic with high fever, rapid breathing.

  • Difficulty swallowing with excessive saliva production (drooling).

  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway, Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)

  • Stridor (noisy breathing during inhalation) is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction.

  • Cyanosis, Coma.

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis

 

  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:

    • Secure airway.

    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.

    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.

  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

questions.text: What recommendation would you provide to alleviate leg cramps for a pregnant woman experiencing discomfort?

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

Explanation:

  • To alleviate an acute leg cramp, patients should actively contract the muscle group opposite to the one affected in order to stretch it. So, a calf cramp can be relieved by dorsiflexing the foot while keeping the knee extended. This commonly suggested method usually offers quick relief from the cramp.

 

Flexing the knee (bending the leg) and dorsiflexing the foot (Option B) may not provide relief for leg cramps. This position can actually exacerbate the cramping sensation by further contracting the muscles.

While extending the knee is recommended, plantar flexing the foot (pointing the toes downwards) may not be effective in relieving leg cramps (Option C). Plantar flexion primarily involves the calf muscles, which may not directly address the cramping muscles.

Flexing the knee and plantar flexing the foot (Option D) may not provide relief for leg cramps. This position may even contribute to muscle tightness and increase discomfort.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be alleviated by performing surgical correction of VSD in an infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Failure to Thrive

Explanation:

Infants with a large VSD can develop heart failure that leads to poor weight gain and inadequate growth, called failure to thrive.

Surgical correction of VSD aims to repair the structural defect, which reduces strain, improves cardiac function, and prevents pulmonary vascular disease. It can enhance the infant's ability to feed, leading to proper weight gain and relieving the feature of failure to thrive.

Indications of surgery in VSD:

  • Large defects in patients of any age who have persistent symptoms or fail to thrive.

  • Moderate to large defects in infants aged 6 to 12 months with pulmonary hypertension, even if symptoms are managed with medication.

  • Children older than 24 months with a Qp:Qs ratio of >2:1.

  • Supracristal VSDs of any size due to an elevated risk of aortic valve regurgitation.

Contraindications for VSD closure:

  • Severe pulmonary vascular disease that does not respond to pulmonary vasodilator therapy.

Respiratory alkalosis (Option A) is not the main acid-base disturbance in VSD. Large VSDs primarily cause metabolic acidosis (due to CHF), not persistent respiratory alkalosis. If respiratory alkalosis occurs, it is secondary to mild tachypnea and not the primary issue requiring surgical correction.

Surgery does not reliably prevent or treat arrhythmia (Option C) and may sometimes increase the risk of it.

Surgical repair does not alleviate heart block (Option D); rather, it is a potential complication of VSD closure and may occur perioperatively.

questions.text: The maternal mortality ratio defined as?

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births

Explanation:

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. This ratio is used to measure the risk of maternal death during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days after delivery.

Formula:

MMR = (Maternal deaths / Live births) × 100,000

  • Maternal death: The death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy due to any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from accidental or incidental causes.
  • Live births: The total number of live births in a given year.

 

Maternal deaths per 10,000 live births (Option A): This is an incorrect scale. The standard measure is per 100,000 live births.

Maternal deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group (Option C): This is also incorrect. MMR is based on live births, not on women in the reproductive age group.

Maternal deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group (Option D): This is not correct because MMR is specifically calculated based on the number of live births, not women in the reproductive age group.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a resident doctor who experiences a needlestick injury while attending to an HIV positive patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Indinavir

Explanation:

  • For a healthcare worker exposed to HIV, such as through a needlestick injury, the recommended treatment is Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP). PEP involves a combination of antiretroviral drugs to reduce the likelihood of HIV transmission.

Current Recommendations:

  • Preferred PEP regimen typically includes a combination of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) like Zidovudine + Lamivudine and a third drug, which is a protease inhibitor (PI) such as Indinavir or an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) like Dolutegravir or Raltegravir.
  • The regimen must be started as soon as possible, ideally within 2 hours, and continued for 28 days

 

Zidovudine + Lamivudine (Option A): This is a 2-drug regimen, which is suboptimal for PEP, as it lacks a third drug, typically an INSTI like Dolutegravir, which is recommended for improved efficacy.

Zidovudine + Lamivudine + Nevirapine (Option B): Nevirapine is an older non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) that is associated with more adverse effects and drug resistance, making it less preferable for PEP in modern guidelines.

Zidovudine + Nevirapine (Option D): This is also a 2-drug regimen and lacks a third drug (an INSTI like Dolutegravir), which is essential for optimal PEP.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the Nikshay Poshan Yojana program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rs 500 is given per month

Explanation:

  • The Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide nutritional support to individuals undergoing treatment for Tuberculosis (TB). The program aims to improve the nutritional status of TB patients, as proper nutrition is essential for effective treatment and recovery.
  • Under this scheme:
    • Rs 500 is provided monthly to TB patients as nutritional support to help them adhere to their treatment and improve overall health.

 

Rs 500 is given per week (Option A): This is incorrect because the scheme provides Rs 500 per month, not weekly.

Mid-day meals are given (Option C): This is not part of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana. The program provides financial support for nutrition, but not direct meal distribution.

Dietary advice is given (Option D): While nutrition is a component, the primary focus of the scheme is financial support for food, not direct dietary counseling.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does not indicate severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thirsty child

Explanation:

Thirst is actually a symptom of dehydration, not specific for severe dehydration. When the body is dehydrated, it sends signals of thirst to encourage the person to drink fluids and replenish the water deficit. Therefore, a thirsty child is more likely to be experiencing some dehydration rather than severe dehydration.

Drowsy child (Option A) is a symptom of severe dehydration. When the body is severely dehydrated, it can lead to altered mental status, including drowsiness or lethargy. Severe dehydration affects the normal functioning of the brain and can result in decreased alertness and responsiveness.

Retraction of skin slowly on pinching (Option B) is also a symptom of severe dehydration. Decreased skin turgor is a sign of dehydration, and in severe cases, the skin may remain tented or retracted due to fluid loss.

Sunken fontanelle (Option D) is another symptom of severe dehydration, especially in infants. The fontanelles are the soft spots on a baby's head where the skull bones have not yet fully fused. If the fontanelle appears sunken or depressed, it suggests significant fluid loss and dehydration.

Assessment and classification of Dehydration in Children:
