questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lumirubin

Explanation:

Phototherapy is used to reduce levels of bilirubin in the blood, particularly in cases of neonatal jaundice. This light interacts with bilirubin, converting it into lumirubin, which is excreted through the kidney without conjugation.

Phototherapy:

Most effective wavelength of light used: 450-460 nm

Mechanisms by which phototherapy acts

  • Photoisomerization

    • Photoisomer of bilirubin forms excreted via bile

    • Slow & reversible

  • Structural Isomerization

    • Bilirubin → Lumirubin → excreted through kidney without conjugation

    • Faster & irreversible

    • Most important mechanism by which phototherapy acts

  • Photo-Oxidation

    • Least important

Effectiveness of phototherapy increases on:

  • Lesser distance between baby and phototherapy unit

  • Higher surface exposure area of the baby

  • LED lamps > CFL lamps

  • Less interruption

Effectiveness does not depend on the skin pigmentation of the baby.

Adverse Effects of Phototherapy:

  • Bronze baby syndrome

  • Dehydration

  • Watery diarrhea

  • Hypocalcemia

  • Retinal toxicity

  • Gonadal toxicity or mutations

  • Impaired maternal-child bonding

Stercobilin (Option A) is a breakdown product of bilirubin that gives stool its characteristic brown color. It is formed in the intestines after bilirubin is metabolized by gut bacteria.

Biliverdin (Option C) is an intermediate compound in the breakdown of heme, which is eventually converted to bilirubin.

Urobilin (Option D) is a breakdown product of bilirubin that is excreted in the urine. It is formed in the intestines from bilirubin by gut bacteria.

questions.text: What is true about vaccination in a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome who is brought to the OPD?

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in the acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

Explanation:

All killed vaccines under the NIS (National Immunization Schedule) can be given to a child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. They have compromised immune systems, making them more susceptible to infections, so live vaccines are not given.

  • Live vaccines can be administered in children receiving prednisolone dose < 1mg/kg daily or 2mg/kg on alternate days.
  • If a patient is receiving steroid-sparing agents, live vaccines are contraindicated.
  • In this case, as the patient is dependent on steroids, he must be receiving a higher dose of steroid/steroid-sparing agents. Hence, live vaccines are contraindicated in this case, as live vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus that can potentially cause the disease in individuals with weakened immune responses. (Option A ruled out)

While the pneumococcal vaccine is important and can be given to a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, it is not the only vaccine (Option C) that should be administered in the acute phase. Full pneumococcal vaccination and influenza vaccination can be given to the child and their household contact.

Immunisation of siblings (Option D) and household contacts with live vaccines are important to reduce the risk of transmission to the immunocompromised child. Direct exposure to gastrointestinal and respiratory secretions is avoided for about 3 -6 weeks after immunization.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigations is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Globin gene sequencing

Explanation:

In this case, the presence of target cells and a history of repeated blood transfusions suggests a possible hemoglobinopathy, such as thalassemia or sickle cell disease.

  • Globin gene sequencing is a molecular diagnostic test that can identify specific mutations or genetic alterations in the globin genes.

  • By sequencing the globin genes, such as the alpha and beta globin genes, it is possible to identify the specific genetic abnormality responsible for the hemoglobinopathy.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Option A) is a commonly used method to measure the different types of hemoglobin and their variants in the blood. While HPLC can help in identifying abnormal hemoglobin variants, it may not provide a definitive diagnosis of the underlying genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy.

Estimating ferritin levels (Option B) can provide information about the iron stores in the body but may not directly help in diagnosing the underlying cause of the anemia or the specific genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy.

While bone marrow examination (Option C) can provide valuable information about the cells in the bone marrow, it may not always be necessary for the definitive diagnosis of hemoglobinopathy

questions.text: What type of vaccine is the Diphtheria vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Toxoid

Explanation:

The Diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine.

  • Toxoid vaccines are made from inactivated toxins produced by bacteria. These toxins are treated to remove their harmful effects while still stimulating the immune system to recognize and fight the toxin if exposed in the future.

For diphtheria, the causative agent Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces a potent toxin that causes the disease. The vaccine contains an inactivated form of this toxin (diphtheria toxoid), which prompts the body to develop immunity without causing the disease.

 

Polysaccharide vaccine (Option A): Polysaccharide vaccines use sugar molecules from the surface of bacteria to stimulate immunity. Diphtheria is not a polysaccharide vaccine.

Killed vaccine (Option C): Killed vaccines use whole pathogens (bacteria or viruses) that are killed or inactivated, but diphtheria is a toxoid vaccine, not a killed bacteria vaccine.

Live attenuated vaccine (Option D): Live attenuated vaccines use a weakened form of the pathogen, but diphtheria vaccines do not contain live bacteria.

questions.text: Which statement is correct regarding the reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the RDA ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Weight 55 kgs

Explanation:

The reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA). This reference is crucial for determining the nutrient requirements of the general population.

  • Weight 55 kgs: The reference woman is typically assumed to have a body weight of 55 kg (121 lbs). This value is used to determine the average energy and nutrient requirements.

 

Height 1.73 m (Option B): While height is a factor in determining nutritional needs, the reference woman is generally assumed to have a height of around 1.60 m (not 1.73 m).

Works 10 hours/day (Option C): The reference woman is not assumed to work for a specific number of hours each day. Nutritional requirements can vary depending on physical activity, but the reference is typically for a woman with moderate activity levels.

Age of 18-25 years (Option D): The reference woman is not specifically limited to this age range. Nutritional needs are assessed based on a range of factors, including age, but the reference woman is generally used as an average for adult women (not limited to a specific age group).

questions.text: Which one of the following methods does not effectively prevent the transmission of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1% glutaraldehyde

Explanation:

  • 1% glutaraldehyde: 1% glutaraldehyde is a chemical used for disinfecting medical instruments, but it is not recommended for general hand hygiene or preventing the transmission of COVID-19. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers or soap and water are far more effective for personal hygiene.

 

Face mask (Option A): Wearing a face mask is an effective measure for preventing the transmission of COVID-19, especially when combined with other protective actions, as it helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets that may contain the virus.

70% alcohol (Option C): Alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing 70% alcohol are highly effective in killing the coronavirus on the hands, reducing the risk of transmission.

Hand washing (Option D): Regular hand washing with soap and water is one of the most effective ways to prevent the spread of COVID-19, as it helps remove the virus from the skin.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Reducing the secretions

Explanation:

  • Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic medication that reduces airway secretions and minimizes bronchospasm by blocking acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. It is especially important for asthmatic patients at risk of increased secretions and bronchoconstriction.

 

Pre-Op medications:

Class of Medication

Common Drugs

Use

Anxiolytics (Option D ruled out)

Midazolam, Lorazepam, Diazepam, Ketamine (pediatrics)
  • Preoperative anxiety reduction
  • Midazolam is preferred for adults due to short half-life and potency.
  • Avoid premedication in pediatric patients < 6 months.

Antiemetics

Ondansetron, Dexamethasone, Metoclopramide, Droperidol, Transdermal Scopolamine
  • Prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

Aspiration Prophylaxis

H2-Receptor Blockers (Ranitidine), Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs)
  • Reduce risk of pulmonary aspiration
  • Effective in reducing gastric acidity and volume.
  • Recommended for patients with conditions like GERD, obesity, or non-fasted status

Antibiotics

 
  • Infection prevention at surgical sites

Anticholinergic

Glycopyrrolate

  • To reduction of secretions (Option A)

Analgesics

Fentanyl (Option D), NSAIDs (Celecoxib)
  • Pain management, opioid dependency
  • Fentanyl is preferred for rapid clearance and potency. - NSAIDs may be given preoperatively to reduce pain.

questions.text: As per biomedical waste management guidelines, in which colored bag should used pacemakers be discarded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Blue

Explanation:

  • According to the Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines, used pacemakers should be disposed of in the blue colored bag, which is designated for non-infectious, recyclable, and discarded electronics.
  • The blue bag is typically used for items like discarded electronics, including pacemakers, that are not considered hazardous or infectious but need to be disposed of safely due to their electronic and metal components.

 

Yellow (Optio A): Yellow bags are used for infectious waste such as human tissues, body fluids, and soiled items.

White (Option B): White bags are typically used for glassware and items that are non-infectious but still require careful disposal.

Black (Option C): Black bags are used for general waste that is non-hazardous, but pacemakers are classified under non-infectious medical waste that needs special handling.

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Nasal cannula

Explanation:

  • A nasal cannula is a medical device used to deliver supplemental oxygen or increased airflow to a patient or person in need of respiratory help.
  • It consists of a lightweight tube that splits into two prongs that are placed in the nostrils. The other end of the tube is connected to an oxygen supply.

Nasal cannula:

  • Used in low to medium concentrations of O2 (22-44%)
  • When these are attached to the flow meter which is connected to the central pipeline supply of an ICU or cylinders and is turned on at 1L per minute, these deliver oxygen of about 24%.
  • Atmospheric oxygen is from 20 to 21%
  • When the concentration of oxygen is increased, it leads to an increase in the concentration of FIO2
  • This device can only deliver up to 6L per minute
  • Every liter corresponds to its subsequent FiO2:
    • 1 L/min-24%
    • 2 L/min-28%
    • 3 L/min-32%
    • 4 L/min-36%
    • 5 L/min-40%
    • 6 L/min-44%
  • This device is not beneficial for a capacity of > 6 liters
  • Advantages: Patients can talk and eat with 02 support when using a nasal cannula and a nasal cannula can be used in home settings.
  • Disadvantages: It may irritate nasal and pharyngeal mucosa. If the flow is given for more than 6L, the FiO2 may vary.

 

Mechanical ventilator (Option A): It is a device used to assist or control a patient's breathing. It delivers a mixture of air and oxygen, controls the respiratory rate and tidal volume, and provides positive pressure to support ventilation. It is more complex than a high-flow nasal cannula and is used in cases where more advanced respiratory support is needed.

Infusion pump (Option B): It is a device used to deliver fluids, such as medications or nutrients, into a patient's body in a controlled manner. It is not related to respiratory support and is used for intravenous administration of fluids or medications.

CPAP machine (Option C): Continuous Positive Airway Pressure is a respiratory therapy used to treat sleep apnea. It involves providing a continuous flow of air pressure to keep the airways open during sleep. A CPAP machine is different from a high-flow nasal cannula, which delivers a high flow rate of oxygen.

questions.text: Which one of the options listed below is a non-parametric test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Friedman test

Explanation:

  • A non-parametric test is one that does not assume a specific distribution for the data, such as normality, and is typically used when the assumptions of parametric tests (like the t-test or ANOVA) are not met. The Friedman test is a non-parametric alternative to the repeated measures ANOVA, used to test differences between groups when the data is paired or repeated.

 

Student t-test (Option A): This is a parametric test, used to compare the means of two groups. It assumes that the data follows a normal distribution.

ANOVA (Option C): Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is a parametric test used to compare means across three or more groups. It assumes normality and homogeneity of variance.

Pearson (Option D): The Pearson correlation coefficient measures the strength of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. It is parametric and assumes normality.

questions.text: As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC), what would be your recommendation for mass prophylaxis/treatment of anemia?

choices.text: FeS04 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

Explanation:

As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC), for mass prophylaxis or treatment of anemia, the most common approach would include a combination of iron (to treat iron deficiency anemia), along with vitamin C (to enhance iron absorption), folate (for folate deficiency), and vitamin B12 (for vitamin B12 deficiency). This combination is effective for treating nutritional anemia and anemia due to multiple deficiencies in populations, particularly in rural or underserved areas.

  • FeSO4 (Ferrous sulfate) is a commonly used form of oral iron.
  • Vitamin C enhances the absorption of iron.
  • Folate and Vitamin B12 address deficiencies that can contribute to anemia, particularly megaloblastic anemia

 

Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose (Option B): This is an oral iron preparation, but it's typically used when iron sulfate is not tolerated due to gastrointestinal side effects. However, it may not be the first choice for mass prophylaxis.

Ferrous fumarate (Option C): Another form of oral iron, but the inclusion of vitamins C, B12, and folate in Option A makes it a more comprehensive approach.

Inj. iron sucrose (Option D): This is an injectable iron preparation used for patients who cannot tolerate oral iron or have severe iron deficiency anemia. However, it is not typically used for mass prophylaxis at the PHC level due to its cost and the need for trained personnel to administer injections.

Central line insertion (Option A): It refers to the placement of a catheter into a large central vein, such as the subclavian vein or internal jugular vein. The image provided does not correspond to instruments commonly used for central line insertion.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a probability distribution that represents the likelihood of a specific number of events occurring within a specific time period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Poisson distribution

Explanation:

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the probability of a specific number of events occurring within a fixed time period or spatial area, given a known average rate of occurrence. It is typically applied in situations where events happen independently and randomly over time, such as the number of calls at a call center, accidents at an intersection, or infections in a population.

 

Binomial distribution (Option A): The binomial distribution models the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials (e.g., flipping a coin or testing a drug's efficacy), where the probability of success is constant for each trial.

Gaussian distribution (Option B): The Gaussian (Normal) distribution is a continuous probability distribution that is used to model variables that tend to cluster around a mean. It is not specific to counting events within a time period.

Normal distribution (Option D): This is another term for the Gaussian distribution, which is used for continuous variables rather than discrete event counts over time.

questions.text:
When would you choose to utilize a sanitizer?


	Prior to conducting a patient examination
	Following a patient examination
	After coming into contact with the patient's environment
	On open wound
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 & 3 only

Explanation:

  1. Prior to conducting a patient examination – Correct. Hand sanitization before patient contact reduces the risk of transmitting infections.
  2. Following a patient examination – Correct. Sanitizing hands after examining a patient prevents cross-contamination.
  3. After coming into contact with the patient's environment – Correct. Contact with surfaces in a patient's vicinity can harbor pathogens, necessitating hand hygiene.
  4. On an open wound – Incorrect. Sanitizers contain alcohol, which can cause irritation and damage to tissue when applied to open wounds.

Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

Effectiveness of Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

  • Contains ethanol, isopropanol, or a mix
  • Effectiveness depends on alcohol type, concentration (60-95%), application technique, and consistency.
  • Ethanol is more effective against viruses, while propanol is better for bacteria.

WHO Definition and Composition
  • Hand sanitizers consist of alcohol (liquid, gel, or foam), excipients, humectants, and sometimes antimicrobial agents (e.g., chlorhexidine for prolonged protection).
  • Higher alcohol concentrations (above recommended levels) can be paradoxically less effective due to reduced protein denaturation.

Indications and Limitations
  • Effective against most bacteria, fungi, and enveloped viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Ebola, Zika).
  • Less effective against protozoan oocysts, non-enveloped viruses (e.g., norovirus, poliovirus), and bacterial spores (e.g., Clostridioides difficile).
  • Ineffective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with certain pathogens.

Contraindications and Risks
  • Can cause skin reactions like dryness, irritation, contact dermatitis, and rarely urticaria.
  • Frequent use may lead to minor alcohol absorption, though considered safe.
  • Fire hazard due to flammability

WHO-Recommended Formulations
  • Ethanol-based (80%) - Ethanol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.
  • Isopropyl alcohol-based (75%) - Isopropyl alcohol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.

Proper Application Technique
  • Apply 2.4 mL sanitizer, rub thoroughly for 15-30 seconds until dry.
  • Some dispensers may not release adequate amounts; users should ensure sufficient application.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be considered effective CPR?

1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute

2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min

3. Allow complete chest recoil

4. 5-6cm deep compression
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 2,3 and 4

Explanation:

  • The CAB algorithm highlights the key elements needed to ensure high-quality CPR in BLS.

 

Compressions (C)

Position: Place the patient in a supine position on a firm surface.

Site: Lower ⅓ rd of sternum

Rate: 100 to 120 compressions per minute. (Statement 2)

Depth: Compress 2 to 2.4 inches (5-6 cm); avoid exceeding 2.4 inches. (Statement 4)

Compression-to-Ventilation Ratio: 30 compressions to 2 breaths (30:2). (Statement 1)

Chest Recoil: Allow full recoil between compressions to optimize blood flow. (Statement 3)

Interruptions: Minimize interruptions in compressions (<10 seconds).

Chest Compression Fraction (CCF): The proportion of time spent performing chest compressions during CPR: Maintain a CCF ≥ 60%.

For pregnant women: perform manual lateral uterine displacement (LUD) to relieve pressure on large abdominal vessels.

Airway (A)

Head Tilt-Chin Lift: Used to open the airway in patients without suspected neck trauma.

Jaw Thrust: Preferred method, if neck trauma is suspected.

The most common cause of airway obstruction in unconscious patients is the tongue falling back.

Breathing (B)

Rescue Breaths: Give 2 breaths after every 30 compressions.

Method: Mouth-to-mouth or with a bag-mask device, ensuring chest rise with each breath.

Breath Duration: Each breath should last about 1 second.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below indicates the degree of heat resistance exhibited by vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VVM

Explanation:

  • The Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) is used to indicate the degree of heat resistance and the extent to which a vaccine has been exposed to heat. It is a color-changing indicator attached to vaccine vials to help assess whether a vaccine has been stored or transported at the correct temperature. This helps in determining if a vaccine remains safe and effective for use.

 

VMV (Option A): There is no known vaccine-related term called VMV.

MVV (Option C): This is not a recognized term related to vaccine heat resistance.

VMM (Option D): This also is not related to heat resistance in vaccines.

questions.text: The absence of the structure will be present in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Explanation:

  • The marked structure shows eosinophilic cells indicative of parietal cells.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which is characterized by excess gastrin secretion from tumours, is not related to the absence of parietal cells.

 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome:

  • Cause: Gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumours (gastrinomas) located mainly in the small intestine or pancreas.
  • Presentation:
    • Duodenal ulcers
    • Chronic diarrhoea
  • Marked increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to parietal cell hyperplasia
  • Gastrin also induces hyperplasia of the mucous neck and endocrine cells.
  • Sporadic, solitary lesions in 75% of cases.
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) in 25% of cases and is associated with younger age, duodenal tumours, and metastasis.
  • Treatment:
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) block acid hypersecretion, promoting ulcer healing and preventing gastric perforation.
    • Focus on treating the gastrinomas, which influence long-term survival.

Pernicious Anemia (Option A) is an autoimmune disorder caused by the destruction of gastric parietal cells, leading to intrinsic factor deficiency. Since intrinsic factor is essential for vitamin B12 absorption in the intestines, its absence results in vitamin B12 deficiency. The loss of parietal cells is a hallmark of pernicious anaemia.

Autoimmune Metaplastic Atrophic Gastritis (Option B) is an autoimmune condition that targets the parietal cells, causing hypochlorhydria (low stomach acid) and a decreased production of intrinsic factors.

Vitamin B12 Deficiency (Option C) can arise from various causes, including pernicious anaemia or inadequate dietary intake. Pernicious anaemia occurs due to the loss or dysfunction of parietal cells, which produce intrinsic factors essential for vitamin B12 absorption. The resulting intrinsic factor deficiency impairs B12 absorption, leading to deficiency.

questions.text: The cells lining the isthmus of gastric pits are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stem cells

Explanation:

  • The isthmus of the gastric pits contains stem cells, which are responsible for replenishing the various cell types in the gastric mucosa.
  • These stem cells differentiate into different types of gastric cells, including parietal cells, chief cells, and mucous cells, as they migrate along the pit.

 

 

Cell Type

Location

Function

Stem cells

Isthmus of gastric pits

Regenerate the various types of gastric epithelial cells.

Parietal cells

Fundus and body of the stomach

It secretes hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factors that are important for digestion and vitamin B12 absorption.

Chief cells

Fundus and body of the stomach

Secrete pepsinogen, which is converted to pepsin in the acidic environment, to aid in protein digestion.

Mucous cells

Surface epithelium of the stomach lining and neck of gastric pits

Secrete mucus to protect the stomach lining from the acidic environment and digestive enzymes.

Endocrine cells (G cells)

Antrum of the stomach

Secrete gastrin, which stimulates acid secretion by parietal cells and gastric motility.

Enteroendocrine cells

Throughout the gastric mucosa

Secrete various hormones such as somatostatin, serotonin, and histamine to regulate gastric functions.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rabies

Explanation:

  • Among these, rabies has the highest case fatality rate (~100%) once symptoms appear, making it the most lethal of the listed diseases.
    • The virus infects the central nervous system (CNS), leading to encephalitis, paralysis, hydrophobia, and coma.
    • No effective treatment after symptom onset, but post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rabies vaccine + immunoglobulin is highly effective if given before symptoms develop.

 

Rabies virus

 

Epidemiological Determinants of Rabies:

Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease?

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries
Improves with food rich in carbohydrates

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

Explanation:

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small intestine, triggered by the ingestion of gluten.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, particularly enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL).

Celiac disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

Synonym
  • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy
  • Celiac sprue

Diagnosis

  • Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum

Serum markers
  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG): Most sensitive
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Most specific

Histology
  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis),
  • Crypt hyperplasia (increased mitosis)
  • Villous atrophy (reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption)
  • Inflammatory cells infiltration

Celiac disease is more commonly diagnosed in developed countries (Option A), particularly among populations of European descent, rather than being the leading cause of malnutrition in developing countries.

CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is not used to diagnose celiac disease (Option B). The diagnosis is typically based on clinical evaluation, serological tests (e.g., anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies), and confirmation through a small bowel biopsy.

Celiac disease does not improve with a carbohydrate-rich diet (Option C). The primary treatment for celiac disease is a strict gluten-free diet, which requires avoiding foods containing gluten.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is correct?


	An arborizing pattern of smooth muscle
	Loss of heterozygosity in STK11 gene
	Multiple GI polyps
	Autosomal recessive inheritance
	Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigmental epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3

Explanation:

Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome:

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.
  • Age of Onset: Median age of 11 years.
  • Key Features:
    • Multiple GI hamartomatous polyps.
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (dark macules on lips, buccal mucosa, palms, genitalia, and perianal region).
    • Polyps are most common in the small intestine but may also occur in the stomach, colon, bladder, and lungs.
  • Complications:
    • Risk of intussusception, potentially fatal.
    • Increased cancer risk (lifetime risk ~40%), including cancers of the GI tract, testes, pancreas, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterus.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • It is caused by germline mutations in the STK11 gene, a tumour suppressor gene regulating cell polarization and growth.
    • Somatic loss of the second STK11 gene copy in cancers.
  • Morphology:
    • Polyps are pedunculated and lobulated.
    • Histology shows an arborizing network of smooth muscle, connective tissue, lamina propria, and glands.

 

 

Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigmental epithelium is not typically associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHTPE) is more commonly seen in other conditions, such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about stem cells?

choices.text: They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

Explanation:

Stem cells can differentiate into various cell types, replicate, and regenerate damaged tissues. However, they do not divide uncontrollably or without regulatory stimuli. Their division is tightly regulated by signalling pathways to ensure proper function and prevent uncontrolled cell proliferation, which could lead to issues like cancer.

Stem cells:

  • Dual property: Stem cells can self-renew (Option B) and differentiate (Option A) into various cell types.

  • Totipotent stem cells: Found during development, can generate all cell types in the body.

  • Adult stem cells: Present in tissues, maintain cell populations, and repair damage (Option D). Limited differentiation capacity, typically producing cells within their respective tissues.

Main types:

  • Embryonic stem (ES) cells: Totipotent, can differentiate into all cell types.

  • Adult (Tissue) stem cells: Limited to differentiating into specific tissue types, regulated by stem cell niches.

Examples:

  • Hematopoietic stem cells: Replenish blood cells in bone marrow, used in clinical treatments like leukaemia.

  • Mesenchymal stem cells: Found in bone marrow and fat, they can differentiate into stromal cells (cartilage, bone, fat, muscle) and aid tissue regeneration.

questions.text: The most common lung finding in a COVID-19 infection is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse alveolar damage

Explanation:

  • The most common lung finding in COVID-19 infections is diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), characterized by injury to the alveolar epithelium and endothelium, leading to pulmonary oedema, inflammation and the formation of hyaline membranes.

 

 

COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2):

  • Transmission:
    • It likely originated from a seafood and animal market in Wuhan.
    • Initial animal-to-human transmission, followed by human-to-human spread.
  • Clinical features:
    • Range from mild flu-like symptoms to severe respiratory illness.
    • Severe cases often involve respiratory compromise and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest imaging.
    • It is more severe in older adults and individuals with comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, COPD, heart failure).
  • Pathology: Histologic analysis of lung tissue shows diffuse alveolar damage and inflammation, primarily with mononuclear cells.

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit?

choices.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted
RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of time only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Human cells can divide a finite number of times only.:

The hayflick limit, discovered by Dr. Leonard Hayflick, states that normal human cells have a finite capacity for replication.

  • Telomeres, protective caps at chromosome ends, shorten with each cell division due to incomplete DNA replication.
  • Shortened telomeres eventually lead to cellular senescence, preventing uncontrolled cell division and potential cancer.
  • Some cells, like stem cells and certain cancers, express telomerase, extending telomeres and bypassing the Hayflick limit.
  • In normal human cells, telomerase activity is limited, leading to replicative senescence.

The Hayflick limit, the maximum times cells can divide, is influenced by several factors:

  • Telomere Length: Shortening telomeres indicate reduced division capacity.
  • Telomerase Activity: Higher activity extends telomeres, bypassing the limit.
  • DNA Damage: Accumulated damage triggers senescence, limiting division.
  • Cellular Stress: Various stressors accelerate senescence, reducing the limit.
  • Genetic Factors: Variations affect telomere maintenance and DNA repair.
  • Environmental Factors: Lifestyle, pollutants, and stress impact cellular health, affecting the limit.

Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted (Option B): The Hayflick limit is not directly related to free radical oxidation levels.

Telomerase activity is unrestricted (Option C): Telomerase activity is typically restricted in normal human cells, unlike stem cells and certain cancers.

RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only (Option D): The Hayflick limit primarily involves telomere shortening, not RNA polymerase function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL)?

choices.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

Explanation:

  • Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) typically has a more favourable prognosis compared to classical Hodgkin lymphoma (HL).
  • It is usually EBV negative, CD30 negative, and CD20 positive, characteristic features of NLPHL. However, it does not generally have a poorer prognosis than classical HL.

 

Subtypes and features of Hodgkin’s lymphoma:

Subtype

Morphology and Immunophenotype

Typical Clinical Features

Nodular Sclerosis
  • Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
  • Background infiltrate includes T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • Fibrous bands divide cellular areas into nodules.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV negative.
  • Most common subtype, typically stage I or II with mediastinal involvement.
  • Equal occurrence in males and females.
  • Common in young adults.

Mixed Cellularity
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells.
  • Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV positive.
  • More than 50% present as stage III or IV.
  • More common in males.
  • Biphasic incidence peaks in young adults and those >55 years.

Lymphocyte-Rich
  • Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV positive.
  • Uncommon, more frequent in males.
  • Typically seen in older adults.

Lymphocyte Depletion
  • Reticular variant with numerous RS cells and few background reactive cells.
  • RS cells: CD15+, CD30+, most EBV positive.
  • Rare, more common in older men, HIV-infected individuals, and low-income regions.
  • Often presents with advanced disease.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant
  • Frequent L&H (popcorn) cell variants in a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells.
  • RS cells: CD20+, CD15−, CD30−; EBV negative.
  • Uncommon, typically in young males.
  • Presents with cervical/axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Rarely involves the mediastinum.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ascaris lumbricoides

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides. The female Ascaris lumbricoides is identified by a straight conical posterior end & a vulvar groove, distinguishing it from the male, which has a ventrally curved posterior end. Females are also larger, measuring 20-40 cm, compared to males at 15-30 cm

Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Incorrect Options:

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option A): This nematode is much smaller and thread-like. It primarily affects the small intestine and is diagnosed via larvae in stool rather than large adult worms. It can cause autoinfection, leading to hyperinfection syndrome in immunocompromised individuals.

Enterobius vermicularis (Option B): Also known as the pinworm, it is much smaller (~1 cm) and resides in the perianal region. It causes perianal itching (especially at night), and diagnosis is confirmed using the Scotch tape test to detect eggs.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option C): This is a hookworm, characterized by its curved morphology and cutting plates/teeth. It causes iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss in the intestines. Infection occurs via skin penetration from contaminated soil.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency?

choices.text: Cells do not lyse in a hypotonic solution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bite cells are present

 

Explanation:

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, oxidative stress leads to the formation of bite cells (also called degmacytes) due to the removal of damaged portions of the cell membrane.

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an inherited enzyme affecting red blood cells.
  • Caused by a lack of the G6PD enzyme, which protects red blood cells from oxidative damage.
  • Oxidative stress makes red blood cells vulnerable, leading to hemolysis.
  • A characteristic feature is the presence of bite cells (degmacytes).
  • Heinz bodies, formed from denatured haemoglobin, are not visible with Romanowsky stains.
  • When Romanowsky stains are used, the denatured haemoglobin may not be detected, resulting in the appearance of bite cells.

Abnormality

Condition

Reason

Bite cells

G6PD deficiency
  • Oxidative stress leads to cross-linking of sulfhydryl groups in haemoglobin → Denaturation of haemoglobin → Heinz bodies.
  • RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen → Splenic macrophages try to pluck these Heinz bodies → Membrane loss → Bite cells.

Target cells

Thalassemia
  • ↓ Haemoglobin content in RBCs → ↓ RBC volume → Surface area relatively unchanged → ↑ Surface area to volume ratio→ Altered lipid composition → ↑ Formation of membrane protrusions→ ↑ Membrane instability → ↓ Hemoglobin accumulation in certain membrane areas → Central area with haemoglobin, clear zone, outer ring.
  • Uneven distribution of haemoglobin and lipids → Characteristic "bull's-eye" appearance of Target cells

Sickle-shaped RBC

Sickle Cell Anemia

Abnormal Hemoglobin (HbS) → HbS molecules polymerize under low oxygen → RBCs become rigid and assume a sickle shape.

 

 

Spherocytes

Hereditary Spherocytosis

Genetic defect in RBC membrane protein(spectrin) ⟶ Loss of membrane surface area ⟶ RBCs become spherical.

 

Spectrin defect (Option A) is a structural protein that maintains the shape and flexibility of red blood cells. Deficiency of spectrin is seen in hereditary spherocytosis, not G6PD deficiency.

Cells do not lyse in hypotonic solution (Option C): In G6PD deficiency, red blood cells are more likely to lyse in hypotonic solutions due to their increased vulnerability to oxidative stress.

Cells lyse in hypertonic solution (Option D): Red blood cells do not typically lyse in hypertonic solutions; instead, they undergo crenation. The lysis occurs more readily in hypotonic solutions, especially in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of her hand is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iron deficiency anemia

Explanation:

  • The image shows koilonychia, a concave nail deformity with raised edges, commonly seen in iron deficiency anaemia. The patient's fatigue and pallor further support this diagnosis.

 

Iron deficiency anaemia:

  • Iron deficiency anaemia can result from dietary lack, impaired absorption, increased iron requirement (e.g., during pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding).
  • Clinical features include Koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, oesophagal webs, pica and intestinal malabsorption, affecting overall nutritional status.

Characteristic changes seen in peripheral smear:

  • Hypochromic: The RBCs appear pale due to decreased haemoglobin content.
  • Microcytic: RBCs are smaller than normal due to decreased haemoglobin synthesis.

 

  • Anisocytosis: There is significant variation in the size of RBCs.
  • Poikilocytosis: RBCs may show abnormal shapes, such as pencil cells, target cells (codocytes), and occasionally, elliptocytes.

 

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anaemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

 

Aplastic anaemia (Option A) is a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, resulting in a reduction of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option B) leads to megaloblastic anaemia and is often accompanied by neurological symptoms such as numbness and tingling.

Hypoalbuminemia (Option D) is characterized by low blood albumin levels. It is associated with Muehrcke's lines, which appear as paired, narrow white bands on the fingernails.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency?

choices.text: Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole and Kcat = 20 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2000 nanomole and Kcat = 50 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec
Km of an enzyme = 4 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec:

Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec:

  • Catalytic efficiency, also known as specificity constant, is a measure of how effectively an enzyme converts substrate to product.
  • It is calculated as the ratio of the catalytic rate constant (Kcat) to the Michaelis constant (Km).
  • Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec: Catalytic efficiency = Kcat / Km = 200 / 2 = 100 per micromole per sec.
  • Catalytic efficiency refers to the measure of how effectively an enzyme catalyzes a specific reaction.
  • It is a measure of the enzyme's ability to convert substrate molecules into products within a given time frame.
  • Catalytic efficiency is commonly expressed using the Michaelis-Menten equation, which relates the rate of the enzymatic reaction to the concentration of the substrate.
  • The two important parameters used to evaluate catalytic efficiency are the turnover number (kcat) and the Michaelis constant (Km).

questions.text: What is the fixation technique employed to examine fat in histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frozen section

Explanation:

  • The frozen section is done for the fixation of fats. It is a technique used to examine tissue samples quickly by freezing them and then cutting them into thin slices for immediate microscopic examination.
  • This method is often preferred for fat tissue examination because it prevents the loss of lipid content, which can be affected by formalin fixation.

 

 

  • Advantages:
    • It provides rapid results & ideal for intraoperative consultations (e.g., determining malignancy during surgery).
    • It is essential for preserving certain tissue components like fat, enzymes, and lipids that might be damaged by formalin fixation.

 

Fixatives & uses:

Technique / Tissue

Fixative

Electron microscopy

Glutaraldehyde

Bone marrow (Trephine biopsy)

Zenker’s fluid

GI biopsy

Bouin’s fluid

Brain

Formalin ammonium chloride

Adrenal biopsy

Orth’s fluid

Pap smear

Ethanol

 

IHC (Immunohistochemistry) (Option A) is used to detect specific proteins or antigens in tissue sections using targeted antibodies. Although IHC can identify markers associated with fat cells, it is not a fixation method for examining fat.

Liquid paraffin (Option C) is not a fixation agent but a mounting medium applied to tissue sections on slides. It provides optical clarity and preserves the specimen but does not fix or preserve fat specifically.

Formalin fixation (Option D) is a commonly used method to preserve tissue samples in histopathology. While it preserves the general structure of tissues, it is not ideal for preserving fat. Formalin can cause partial extraction of fat, leading to the loss of fat droplets and artefacts during tissue processing.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man, after being involved in a road traffic accident (RTA), was brought to the casualty 6 hours later. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and SpO2 was 92%. A blood transfusion was administered. A few hours later, the patient becomes febrile and tachypneic and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels begin to drop. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transfusion reaction

Explanation:

The patient's fever, tachypnea, bleeding from IV and NG tube sites, and declining SpO2 after transfusion suggest an acute transfusion reaction, likely due to an immune response causing hemolysis, shock, and DIC.

Types of Transfusion reactions

Aspect

Immediate Transfusion Reactions

Delayed Transfusion Reactions

Onset

Within hours of transfusion

Days to weeks after transfusion

Cause

Immunologic reactions, hemolytic or non-hemolytic

Immune-mediated, often involving minor antigen sensitization

Presentation

Fever, chills, dyspnea (TRALI, TACO), Acute respiratory distress (TRALI), Pulmonary oedema (TACO), hypothermia, electrolyte abnormalities, coagulopathy, acid-base disorders and hyperkalemia.

Fever, jaundice, gradual decline in haemoglobin levels (hemolysis).

 

Severity

Can range from mild to life-threatening.

Generally less severe than immediate reactions.

Examples
  • Febrile non-hemolytic reaction (FNHTR)
  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Delayed hemolytic reaction

Management
  • Stop transfusion and manage symptoms.
  • Supportive care (e.g., antipyretics, oxygen).
  • Monitor for worsening anaemia and hemolysis.
  • Consider further transfusion support if indicated.

questions.text: The JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycythemia vera

Explanation:

  • In polycythemia vera (>95% cases), the JAK2 mutation leads to the persistent activation of the JAK-STAT signalling pathway, resulting in the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of red blood cell precursors.
  • This overproduction increases red blood cell count in the bloodstream, leading to blood thickening and potential complications like thrombosis.

 

Essential thrombocytosis (Option B) is characterized by the overproduction of platelets in the bone marrow, increasing the risk of abnormal blood clotting. Although JAK2 mutations can occur in essential thrombocytosis, they are less frequent compared to polycythemia vera.

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML) (Option C) is primarily associated with the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. This translocation leads to the creation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which causes uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells.

Primary myelofibrosis (PMF) (Option D) involves the excessive production of abnormal blood cells, often leading to fibrosis (scarring) of the bone marrow. JAK2 mutations can also occur in primary myelofibrosis, though they are less common than in polycythemia vera.

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - DNA replication:

  • Mismatch repair: DNA methylation is not directly involved in mismatch repair, which primarily corrects errors introduced during DNA replication, such as base mismatches. It relies on recognizing the newly synthesized strand, not methylation.

DNA methylation involves adding a methyl group to cytosine residue in DNA.

  • Types of DNA methylation: CpG methylation and Non-CpG methylation
  • Enzymes involved: DNA methyltransferases

Functions:

  • Chromatin remodeling: DNA methylation affects chromatin structure by recruiting proteins (e.g., methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins) that compact chromatin, influencing gene expression.
  • DNA replication: DNA methylation patterns are maintained during replication by DNA methyltransferases, ensuring epigenetic inheritance.
  • Gene silencing: DNA methylation at promoter regions suppresses transcription, leading to gene silencing.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same core pathology, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alzheimer’s disease

Explanation:

Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and multisystem atrophy are all associated with alpha-synuclein pathology, specifically the formation of Lewy bodies in the brain.

In contrast, Alzheimer's disease is primarily characterized by the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles of tau protein, representing a different core pathology.

Parkinson’s Disease (PD):

  • Genetic Basis:
    • Autosomal Dominant PD: Caused by mutations in SNCA, which encodes α-synuclein, the key component of Lewy bodies.
    • Autosomal Recessive PD: Linked to mutations in DJ-1, PINK1, and Parkin.
    • Most Common Autosomal Dominant Mutation: LRRK2 (Leucine-Rich Repeat Kinase 2).
  • Clinical Features: Triad of Tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross pathology: Pallor of the substantia nigra due to neuronal loss.
    • Microscopic features:
      • Lewy bodies: Cytoplasmic, eosinophilic inclusions, either single or multiple.
      • Structure: Dense core surrounded by a pale halo.
      • Ultrastructure: Composed of fine filaments of α-synuclein.

 

 

Protein

Associated Disease(s)

Aβ (Amyloid-beta)

Alzheimer disease

Tau

Alzheimer's disease, Frontotemporal lobar degeneration

LRRK2 mutations

Parkinson disease

α-synuclein

Parkinson's disease, Multiple system atrophy

TPD-43

Frontotemporal lobar degeneration, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

FUS

Frontotemporal lobar degeneration, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

Polyglutamine aggregates

Huntington's disease, Some forms of spinocerebellar ataxia, Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy

Tau (with other symptoms)

Progressive supranuclear palsy, Corticobasal degeneration, Chronic traumatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following caspases binds to Cyt c and the APAF-1 complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Caspase 9

Explanation:

  • In the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, the release of cytochrome c (Cyt c) from the mitochondria triggers the formation of the apoptosome, a complex consisting of Cyt c, apoptotic protease-activating factor 1 (APAF-1), and procaspase 9. This complex is essential for initiating the caspase cascade that leads to cell death.

 

Apoptosis (Caspase-dependent programmed cell death):

  • Apoptosis is a type of cell death that is induced by a tightly regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells’ genomic DNA and nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.
  • It is an active process.
  • It eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction, thus limiting collateral tissue damage.
  • Apoptosis results from activating enzymes called caspases, leading to DNA fragmentation.
  • The process of apoptosis may be divided into an initiation phase, during which caspases 8,9,10 become catalytically active and unleash a cascade of other caspases, and an execution phase, during which the terminal caspases 3,6,7 trigger cellular fragmentation.
     

Morphological features:-

  • Cell shrinkage
  • Chromatin condensation
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies, usually by macrophages.


Histopathology: In H&E-stained tissue, the apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.

The above image shows apoptosis of an epidermal cell in an immune reaction. The cell is reduced in size and contains brightly eosinophilic cytoplasm and a condensed nucleus

 

Types:

Apoptosis occurs in two broad contexts:

  • Physiological apoptosis.
  • Pathological apoptosis.

Apoptosis in physiological conditions 

Apoptosis in pathological conditions

1. The removal of supernumerary cells (in excess of the required number) during development.

2. Involution of hormone-dependent tissues on hormone withdrawal, such as endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle.

3. Elimination of potentially harmful self-reactive lymphocytes to prevent immune reactions against one’s own tissues.

4. Death of host cells that have served their useful purpose, such as neutrophils in an acute inflammatory response and lymphocytes at the end of an immune response.

1. DNA damage.

2. Accumulation of misfolded proteins

3. Apoptosis can be induced during infections such as adenovirus, HIV, and viral hepatitis.

4. It may also contribute to pathologic atrophy in parenchymal organs after duct obstruction, such as occurs in the pancreas, parotid gland, and kidney

questions.text:
A patient presented with meningitis, a 4-day history of fever, and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel or tick bite. CSF findings showed:


	Increased protein
	Normal glucose
	Mild lymphocytosis
	Few RBCs


Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) West Nile virus

Explanation:

Enterovirus is the most common cause of viral (aseptic) meningitis,

  • The CSF profile suggests viral (aseptic) meningitis, characterized by:
    • Mild lymphocytosis (predominance of lymphocytes) → Viral etiology
    • Normal glucose → Bacterial meningitis usually causes low CSF glucose
    • Few RBCs → Suggests viral-induced microhemorrhages, often seen in West Nile virus (WNV) or Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Erythematous rash on the chest → Can be seen in viral infections

 

West Nile Virus (Option A): Flavivirus transmitted by mosquitoes (Culex species) but can occur without a travel history in endemic regions.

  • Causes viral meningoencephalitis with CSF lymphocytosis, normal glucose, and RBCs (due to microvascular hemorrhages).
  • Maculopapular rash (often on the chest) is a common feature.

Neisseria meningitidis (Option B): Causes bacterial meningitis, which presents with:

  • High neutrophils (not lymphocytes) in CSF
  • Low CSF glucose
  • Elevated protein
  • Rash is usually petechial (purpura fulminans), not a diffuse erythematous rash.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): Also causes bacterial meningitis with:

  • High neutrophils
  • Low glucose
  • No rash (rash is not a common feature).

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiencies will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Factor XII

Explanation:

  • Factor XII deficiency (Hageman factor) does not significantly affect clotting in vivo, as it primarily participates in the intrinsic pathway and is involved in the activation of the fibrinolytic system and the contact activation of the clotting cascade.
  • Factor XII does not notably impair normal clotting, as other factors and pathways can compensate for its lack.
  • In contrast, Factor VII, Factor V, and Factor IX deficiencies significantly impact the clotting cascade and lead to bleeding disorders.

 

 

Factor VII (Option A) is a critical component of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. Deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders, as it directly impacts the initiation of the clotting cascade in vivo.

Factor V (Option B) is essential for the common pathway of coagulation, acting as a cofactor for Factor Xa in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. Its deficiency results in impaired clotting and increases the risk of bleeding.

Factor IX (Option D) is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Deficiency causes Hemophilia B, leading to impaired clot formation and increased bleeding risk in vivo.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic hypermutation

Explanation:

  • Affinity maturation is a process where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation in germinal centers, leading to the production of antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen.
  • This occurs after the initial IgM response, resulting in the production of IgG (or other classes) with enhanced specificity and effectiveness.

Antibody formation involves B cell activation upon encountering an antigen.

  • The initial response produces IgM, which can then undergo class switching to produce other antibody types like IgG, IgA, and IgE.
  • This process is crucial for mounting an effective immune response against pathogens, with IgG being the most abundant antibody in serum and providing long-term immunity.

The formation of antibodies, or immunoglobulins involves multiple cellular components and steps:

  1. Antigen Encounter and Recognition
    • The process begins when B cells encounter a specific antigen. This antigen must be recognized as foreign to activate the adaptive immune response.
    • B cell receptors (BCRs) on the surface of B cells bind to the antigen. This recognition is highly specific and depends on the unique variable regions of the immunoglobulin on BCRs.
  2. Activation of B Cells
    • Upon binding with the antigen, B cells become activated, which requires help from T helper (Th) cells.
    • T cells are required to release cytokines and co-stimulatory signals, which aid in the full activation of B cells, especially in the case of protein antigens.
  3. Proliferation and Clonal Expansion
    • Activated B cells undergo clonal expansion, where they proliferate to create identical cells that can produce the same specific antibody.
    • This clonal expansion amplifies the immune response, ensuring that a sufficient number of cells are available to target the pathogen.
  4. Differentiation into Plasma Cells and Memory B Cells
    • Following expansion, B cells differentiate into two main cell types:
      • Plasma Cells: These are the effector cells that actively secrete antibodies. Plasma cells are responsible for producing large quantities of antibodies, which are then released into the bloodstream.
      • Memory B Cells: These cells are long-lived and retain the memory of the specific antigen. Upon subsequent exposure to the same antigen, memory B cells can quickly initiate a secondary immune response, leading to a faster and more robust production of antibodies.
  5. Antibody Class Switching
    • Initially, B cells produce IgM antibodies. However, with the help of Th cells, B cells can undergo a process called "class switching" to produce other types of antibodies like IgG, IgA, or IgE.
    • Class switching allows the immune system to adapt the type of antibody produced to the specific requirements of the immune response, depending on the nature of the pathogen and the location of the infection.
  6. Affinity Maturation
    • Affinity maturation occurs in the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues and involves the somatic hypermutation of antibody genes.
    • This process leads to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for the antigen, allowing for a more effective immune response.
  7. Memory and Long-Term Immunity
    • Memory B cells generated during the primary response ensure long-term immunity. If the same antigen is encountered again, these cells quickly respond by differentiating into plasma cells and producing antibodies.
    • This secondary immune response is usually faster and more intense due to the Spresence of these memory cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Isotype switching (Option A): Isotype (class) switching alters the constant region of the antibody (e.g., IgM → IgG, IgA, or IgE) without affecting antigen specificity. It allows adaptation of antibody function but does not directly enhance antigen affinity.

mRNA splicing (Option C): This process regulates antibody expression (e.g., membrane-bound vs. secreted forms of immunoglobulins) but does not enhance antigen affinity.

VDJ rearrangement (Option D): This occurs during B cell development in the bone marrow, generating primary antibody diversity. However, it is not responsible for post-activation affinity maturation.

questions.text: What does the vacutainer tube depicted in the provided image contain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clot activator

Explanation:

  • Clot activator is found in red-top vacutainer tubes and is used to promote blood clotting, which is needed for serum separation in various tests.

 

Vacutainer Color

Additive

Purple/Lavender

Blue

Green

Red
